description:
Came here on a Sunday around noon and had s to wait a bit before getting seated. The waiting area is not big and felt like we were a bit crowded by the door.

After we got seated, we ordered. They were out of the lai fun, so we had to choose something else. I know they are known for their beef stew and found out also their wontons, so I got the both in my noodles. I opted for the egg noodles instead of the flat kind.

After the food came, the portion was a decent amount with beef stew, wontons, a couple pieces of choy, and noodles. I actually thought there was a bit too much noodles. But it was all tasty and I finished it all and most of the broth. 

Next time I come, I would like to try either the lai fun or the flat noodles instead.
author: Karen Y.

description:
I was initially very excited to eat here. The prices looked great and they had a good health score! The food was indeed yummy, but near the end of my meal I discovered a bizarre noodle with a black streak along the whole noodle. I wasn't sure what it was so I asked the waiter who seemed to just laugh and express surprise that I cared about such things. He didn't speak English so I have no idea what he was saying. 

Fortunately that was the only bad noodle in my soup, but it was concerning. Also the waiter's lack of concern was equally concerning. 

I score it a 1 Star for the indifference towards my question about the black noodle in my soup. It looked like mold but I have no idea what it was caused by. See photo for the black streak along the noodle. Would you want to eat that?

I have eaten won ton noodle soup for decades and never encountered a black streaked fungal looking noodle in my soup and had a waiter laugh about it before.
author: Nick L.

description:
I've always passed this place on my way home and decided to go in for some chicken fried rice. There 2 ladies sitting and I let them know that I wanted to order chicken fried rice. One of the ladies told me they don't serve fried rice. I asked her again, just so I could be clear that I had heard her correctly the 1st time, and she told me they don't serve fried rice. I looked up there menu and, sure enough, they have fried rice on the menu. 

I don't know why she would tell me that. I only have 2 guesses. Either she thought I was there to rob the place or she was being a racist mofo.

Either way I will not be going back, after all there are other spots to get fried rice in Chinatown.

If I could give them a zero or minus numbers I would.
author: Brett Y.

description:
Am fairly impressed with their food as my first time visiting this cafe. Wanted to get a simple bowl of wonton noodles in Chinatown with my parents and was recommended to come try this place out. And to my surprised, it was better than I expected. 

I ordered the regular Shrimp Wonton Noodles Soup while my parents got the Beef Stew Wonton Noodles Soup. The size of the shrimp wontons were just your average wonton size and average on meatiness, but the noodles were very bouncy and had a nice texture to the taste. My parent's Beef Stew were something they could not stop raving about. The beef were tender and soft, not chewy at all and very flavorful. Also for the price of each bowl (Shrimp Wonton $5.95; Beef Stew $6.25), you really can't ask for more... 

Overall experience was great. Food was good and cheap, restaurant was small but clean. I would definitely come back again when I'm looking for a place to eat in Chinatown!
author: Stacey T.

description:
Under new management, new ownership and completely remodeled.  They changed their Chinese name and logo but in English, the restaurant remained Utopia Cafe!!

What used to be spot famous for "clay pot rice" changed hands and is now a spot for wonton and/ or beef stew noodles.  Really good prices for solid wonton noodles that rival Hung's wontons.  Com'on.... where can you find wonton noodles for $5.95 these days!?!  The classic slightly crunchy wonton mein with the classic pork and shrimp wontons.... tasty and doubles the portion of Hung's.

I thought that the beef stew noodles were a bit too salty (they added some beef stew juice into the soup )... that made it more flavorful but also a bit too salty for me.  Other than that, solid noodles at bargain prices!

Also, vege dishes here is only $5.50!  Other nearby places easily double the price. 

Stick with the classics here - you can't go wrong.
author: Winnie W.

description:
Cute, casual noodle soup spot in Chinatown.  I had the noodle soup with wontons & BBQ duck, which was delish. Especially the BBQ duck on top! 

Try the honey lemon iced tea!
author: Julia A.

description:
Utopia Cafe is a nice and simple little spot in San Francisco's Chinatown which is known for their beef stew noodle soup.

I came here on a Sunday afternoon for lunch with a group of three. As noted in many other reviews, the service is a bit troublesome here, but the food is not bad. I decided to try their beef stew & wonton noodle soup. They allow for a variety of different noodles and I opted for the egg noodles. My party also ordered their rice rolls to share. The rice rolls were pretty bland with the peanut sauce. There isn't much flavor to them and I would probably opt for something else. The beef stew & wonton noodle soup was pretty good especially for the cheap price. The portion is a little smaller than most places, making it great for a light lunch or afternoon snack. The wonton was great and the beef was surprisingly tender and flavorful.
author: Joshua M.

description:
After opening for about a month, this was my Sunday lunch spot recently.  I tried one other occasion but they close on Tuesdays.  

Though being relatively late in the lunch shift 1:30 pm, all tables were occupied so I shared a table with a couple.  After thumbing through their menu, I ordered an appetizer and a light meal.

Not wanting a heavy starter I started with curry fish balls (https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=gRRgBjyhu_TEJDFUNe-V1g&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q).  Not knowing whether they were premade or fresh, the balls were tasty with no brininess and the curry sauce was just right flavor and spice wise.  My main meal was the beef stew wonton noodles soup (https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=3Xz2Lv84mc1BnF-_szTyag&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q).  The wonton was okay with a mix of mostly ground pork and some shrimp as were the noodles which were Hong Kong style egg noodles, thin and chewy.  The protein was a mix of beef stew and tendons that were braised in a tasty five spice sauce.  Wished there were more meaty pieces than tendons but above average rendition.

The owners are multiple restaurant owners based from Toishan, best known for their Yin Du Wonton Noodle on Pacific Avenue.  

The Chinese name reads as 'beef noodle king', a change from the original which translates to "true happy porridge".  This restaurant no longer serves their famed congee nor do they offer their signature clay pot rice offerings.

This should be listed as a new restaurant, but, as many Chinese restaurants do in saving business registration and beer/wine licenses, they keep the English name intact.  Not a destination eating place, but not bad for neighborhood local fare.
author: Mike C.

description: CASH ONLY. Mom and I saw the sign after ordering and we had to pull out a ton of quarters in change to pay. Luckily, we made it and were very satisfied with the food for its cheap prices. I ordered pork chop ramen and the meat was delicious. The broth was very soothing and definitely filling.
author: Maricar D.

description:
I rate it low because of a man's attitude. I bought a to go here today. Total was 19.19$. I gave him 20.20$ when I picking my food. However, he seems did not want to give back my change. He just stood there and did not care me. Until I ask him "is one dollar considering as tips?", they looked at me and said, "Yes! Is it Ok?" Of course I said ok but I don't like that he asked me to give tips mandatorily. I don't like this feeling. I think I'll never go back.

I didn't take any pictures and it's my first time I use this app to complain a restaurant.
author: Ping H.

description:
service  - Came in with my Argentinian friend and they gave us iced water without asking if we wanted tea or water. Which is hilarious because everyone else around us received tea instead. refused to take our order and forced us to move our seats so another party can squeeze in with our small table.
Food - is decent for its price. A good comprehensive menu for a quick lunch.
author: Xi K.

description:
I have probably gone to this place 10+ times since new management. The beef stew is the main staple of their menu and it's very good! Or it used to be... recently I have noticed that the amount of beef stew to noodles or rice ratio is almost laughable. This time my fiancé and I ordered beef stew noodle soup and beef stew lo mein. The noodle soup was 98% noodles and the rest was VERY fatty meat. Surprising because I used to get a fair helping of beef stew but this time was literally less than 5 pieces of meat.

I was very disappointed in my fiancé's food, the beef stew lo mein. Same issue, only a few pieces of beef. Even worse, ALL OF IT WAS FAT. Not a single actually piece of meat. It's like they trimmed the fat pieces off the meat and dropped them on his plate. VERY DISAPPOINTING AND INEDIBLE. I understand quality dipping a little due to higher demand or more popularity, but this is horrible. If you see in the picture, it's all fat and tendon. We did not order beef tendon...let alone a plate of pieces of fat. 

We were basically served trash pieces :/
author: Meg W.

description:
First visit and probably not a great day to have hot soup (70's and muggy), but, we did.  We started with the rice noodle roll.  A tart sesame seed dressing topped the generous portion of rice noodle rolls.  Too much for 2, but, that did not stop us.  Adding some red chili hot sauce made them even more tasty.   

We both ordered the #11, beef stew with won ton noodle soup with thick tube-like rice noodles.  After the rice noodle appetizer, too much rice noodles!  The bowl was filling, came with 5-6 pieces of beef (fatty and with chewy sinew), 2 stalks of veg that I cannot remember the name for and 4 tasty won-ton.  The broth was deliciously beefy in flavor.  By itself without the appetizer this would have made a nice lunch, alone.

Is this the best I've ever had?  Probably not, but, I thoroughly enjoyed it.  I was really struck by the flavorful broth.  

The place (according to other yelp reviews) has been remodeled and changed ownership.  My friend also said the Chinese characters on the signage was not Utopia Café, but, Beef Stew Noodle.  The place was filled with Chinese patrons.  The place is nice looking, spotless and I will come again.  Yum
author: Donna H.

description: A solid A-OK for this intensely affordable, very humble noodle joint. The signature wonton / beef scrap / pork chop noodle soups are huge and all cost about $5.75-$6.75, which is a rarity in SF these days. The soup is not bad, and the noodles are okay-springy. The proteins are understandably scant for the price, but what do you expect? Not bad.
author: Ken H.

description: The poached pork liver is amazing! We ordered one serve and ended up ordering another one for to-go.
author: Shiyu C.

description:
Very delicious food ! Beef is tender and love the fried chicken wings !!!

Price is reasonable ! Strongly recommended !
author: Josh Z.

description: We stumble upon this place when we drove in SF late and was hungry for good food. We sat down close to closing and got the 2 people combo. We choose the clay pot rice and it hit the spot! Very good home cooking flavors and will visit again! This place is in the heart of China town and not too far of a walk from union square
author: Junie H.

description: Great hole-in-the-wall place.  Best won ton noodle in Chinatown in terms of taste and price.... extremely authentic Hong Kong flavor.
author: Lawrence L.

description:
My go to spot for Clay pots in the chinatown.  I'm not a fan of the bitter melon, but they make it edible here.  I normally get the chinese sausage and chicken clay pot.  Might have to try all the clay pots one day.

Just a great place to get some good chinese food.  Can't complain about the price either.
author: Lyman C.

description: There is no more claypot rice here, which is sort of what this place was known for. This is a brand new establishment with a new owner. Please delete the photos of claypot rice, so that users don't come here disappointed to find that there is none. Or just bring back the claypot rice!
author: Jenny H.

description:
The guy at our hotel suggested this place. I really think it must be his sister's restaurant or something. 

We actually left before our food came. The wontons have shrimp in them. Apparently that's common, but we didn't know it, it didn't say it on the menu, and they were kind of dicks about it.

The whole ambiance creeped us out, so we bailed.
author: Marshall J.

description: Great traditional Hong style noddle place when you're in a hurry and cheap. I enjoy their wonton and brisket noddle. If you want service, you need to way your hand.
author: Herrick K.

description: Changed ownership, service is not good and fewer options. Lame.
author: Debbie Y.

description:
Came on a Sunday night at around 7pm. Only around 20% full. My friend grew up in SF recommended this place to me having the best clay pot rice in town, so decided to give it a try.

#Soup (free): A.
Yes I have to talk about this soup. It was really good and served for free! I think they put red carrot, green carrot, pork bone and some other ingredients in it. Clearly the soup has been boiled for a very long time otherwise it wouldn't have a rich taste to it. My friend and I had 3 small bowls each of this soup. Wish we could have more!

#Preserved Meat Clay Pot Rice 臘味煲仔飯: A-.
Pretty good. Not to a point that I would say it's exceptional but the preserved meats were very tasty (sometimes with low quality preserved meat they could taste bland) and they put a lot of meat inside. One of the key point of clay pot rice is the overcooked rice at the very bottom of the pot (飯焦) - those are usually brownish-black color literally taste like burned rice but with the absorption of soy sauce from the top, it's one of the most unique and good flavor one can ask for. And yes, this clay pot has got it right! Although it would be even better if it's overcooked even more.

#Garlic Pea Sprout: A.
The vege was fresh, garlic amount and cooking time was just about right. Very nice.

Will definitely come back and try other clay pot rice flavors!
author: Simon C.

description:
This place might be small but the food is one of the best in China town.

Service was fast 

Their clay pot rice is fantastic

Taste just right

Veggie and meat are both fresh
author: Mack A.

description:
One of the most unique cantonese place in Chi-town SF. Claypot is their speciality. And Claypot rice is one of thing that you have to eat here!
My fave are pork w/ preserve veggie clay pot rice, spare rib claypot rice, chinese sausage chicken claypot rice. You can also order large size for a larger group.
Secret trick, once you finish munching on the rice, ask for soup to loosen the burnt/chared rice that stick on your claypot.
author: Dan A.

description: Got the veggie clay pot and I didn't think it was anything special. It was tofu, onions, and not many other vegetables. Good portion size though.
author: Emily H.

description:
Guys. I debated on writing this review, only because my friend really likes this place and knows the owner. But, seriously this is a no, no, no! The fish tank next to the bathroom in the main dining room had 2, maybe 3 dead fish. The water was so dark I couldn't tell. Yes, dead fish! Then when you hit the bathroom the overwhelming odor of bleach damn near punches you in the face. Not to mention the dirty garbage bin, compost bin AND mop that hasn't been changed probably since never! Lord have mercy. I am eating here? Do my friends not know me, or where they punishing me for something?  

The one star is for the food and service. Honestly, the food was amazing! Each plate that arrived: the shrimp fried rice, Sweet and Sour Chicken, Mongolian Beef, Vegetable Pan Fried Noodles, the dumplings, everything was so flavorful! I really am glad that it was only after my meal that I saw the dead fish, and condition of the bathroom otherwise I would have said Happy Birthday to my friend and bounced!
author: Jaylena P.

description:
Good spot in Chinatown for claypot rice! Authentic as it gets without the grimeyness of a hole in the wall restaurant in Chinatown. I don't know. Because I feel like cheap, authentic food usually means dirty hole in the wall. Thankfully that's not the case here!!

They got it down with the crispy edges on the bottom. Yyyyyyyyyyyyyas. Came with complementary soup (clearish broth with carrot and lotus root) that reminded me of what my mom/dad make at home.

We also got the beef stir fried flat noodle which was alright considering their specialty is the claypots.

Approved!
author: Emily C.

description:
I was fiendin' for clay pot rice so I ventured to Utopia Cafe as per 7x7's recommendation. It was packed at 6:30pm on a Saturday night, so that was reassuring. Service was quite slow, but you are quite foolish if you expect attentive service at a Chinese restaurant.

We started the meal with complimentary wintermelon and pork soup. It was lukewarm, but hey, free is free.

Salted fish and minced pork rice in clay pot: This made 7x7's Big Eat 2014 list, and I don't quite understand why. The dish lacked the characteristic crispy rice at the bottom of the clay pot, and the topping was satisfactory at best. The strongest flavor came from the saltiness of the salted cod. This dish was overall rather disappointing.

Braised Tofu & Mushrooms: I recommend this dish. My friend who claimed to not like tofu actually really liked this dish. But then again, this was his first time having tofu outside of a cafeteria.

I don't see myself returning here. My hunt for bomb clay pot rice continues. I'm sure I'll find something in Chinatown.
author: Lucy N.

description:
Trying to get through the list means exploring new places to eat and having fun while doing so. Since there was a slow day at work, my coworker and I decided to go up to Chinatown and grab some food. 

We ordered:
Soup - I think we got this for free? I'm not even sure. It was pretty good regardless. 
Clay pot with salted fish and minced pork - really was a good dish, but since there was so much rice, it was really hard to mix together. Although when it was mixed, it was delicious. Just beware of the fish bones! 
Mongolian beef - came out earlier than our other dish. But the Mongolian beef wasn't bad. Definitely was a great accompaniment to our rice. 

They definitely have a great tea - so definitely get it. 

Overall, service is as you expect at a Chinese restaurant, but the food was great too. I did wish that they brought the food out together...or at least a little more together. Not waiting 5 mins between dishes - even though we were sharing.

Protip: those clay pots are great.
author: Nina Y.

description: Fu Jian fried rice was great! Plenty of food. Weird that they charged me an extra $0.35 bc I had a baby. Not sure what that was about.
author: Cindy K.

description:
There was a hair stuck inside our garlic spareribs tonight. They made us a new dish, charge us for it. Lastly, the server didn't give us our change and yelled across the register- "you don't change, right?" Never coming back again. 
I've eaten here at least 3 other times. Without incident but today was horrible. Never going back.
author: Julie T.

description:
They are known for clay pot rice so get one!

Takes about 20 minute for the clay pot rice to be done.
author: Alice X.

description:
One of the best Chinese Restaurants in SF. There Won Ton soup and General Chicken is delicious! I have eaten here several times and they are consistently on the mark!

4th visit. Best won ton soup and General Chicken in Northern Calif.  out of the at, one block above Grant Avenue. A must try!!!
author: Jim B.

description: Enjoyed my Roasted duck wonton soup. Large portion very satisfying. Includes wonton, roasted duck, noodles in a wonderful broth. I've had better broth however this satisfied the soul. Primarily locals with the occasional tourist. Service was friendly and quick.
author: Glenn M.

description: It's quiet and the food is so good! We ordered steamed fish, stirred fried beef with broccoli, cuttlefish clay pot rice, spicy & sour soup. I will say the soup is not better than My China in SF Westfield. The steamed fish is so fresh and it tastes sweet. The beef is so tender. Just remember to remain them to put less oil on the dish!
author: Vanessa Z.

description: I happened to come to Utopia a year ago and definitely fell in love with this place ever since. I always ordered the combo for two persons, which comes with a daily soup, a dish of fresh vegetables, a steamed fish, a clay pot of your choice, and dessert soup, for only $30+. Their clay pot is the best in town. One thing that i really like about Utopia is they use fresh ingredients. I have taken my Chinese friends to this place and they all like it.
author: Yue W.

description:
I came here with my friend for lunch after we finished our class from school. I came here because I saw the good review for the clay pot in this place. I really want to eat the beef in cray pot with raw egg since I ate the best one when I went to HongKong with my family. Then I found this place where serve the Hongkong style food. I order minced beef with raw egg in the cray pot which the waitress said it will take 20 mins and my friend got beef Chow Fan. I eat my friend Cho Fan and I like the taste of the noodle, it's not to salty but my friend said it teastless. For my clay pot it come with the soy sauce on the side(?) and big bok choy on topped. I couln't find my raw egg but I found cookes egg underneath. That's fine I can eat it. Overall for my cray pot is good. Just good when I added soy sauce because if I didnt add it my dish taste nothing.  
Anyway, I like it. May come back to try it again next time. :)
author: Orange S.

description: It's Chinese new year parade time!  So have to get some authentic Chinese cuisine.  I had the BBQ pork wonton noodles.  Big bowl little price  :-).  The bbq pork flavor was spot on.
author: Mary H.

description:
We were walking through Chinatown the other night and saw this place full of Chinese customers and figured it must be better than the last place we tried on Grant. I saw on Yelp how mixed the reviewers were, but we decided to give it a shot. We had the Chinese sausage and dried duck claypot and the "wet" beef chow fun (or, what I think is more commonly called "beef chow fun with gravy") that some Yelpers recommended.  

The lady serving us was very nice, helping me along with my broken Cantonese. And we were surprised to get a very tasty wintermelon soup to start off our meal. I had requested a red bean ice (on the Chinese menu), but they were out. She told us, though, that the meals came with sweet green bean soup for dessert -- much better than fortune cookies, IMO.  I mention this because overall ambiance can have an impact on taste and these things put us in a pretty good mood for our meal. 

We thoroughly enjoyed both dishes. The claypot came with a good serving of bok choi on top, much to our delight.  The sauce was on the side, which kept things more fresh tasting.  The meats included two types of Chinese sausage/laap cheung (liver and regular), as well as the most buttery-tasting dried pork I have had, plus the salted dried duck. The best part of the claypot, though is scraping the crispy rice (faan jiu) off the inside of pot - so good. The beef chow fun with gravy was also very tasty. I usually prefer the dried style (one of the hardest dishes for a Chinese cook to get just right), but I would definitely have the gravy version again here (which also came with bok choi).

Also, when we first got there it was not very busy and most of the customers were non-Chinese tourists (something that makes me cautious), but by the time we left it was almost full and most of the customers were Chinese (Cantonese).

Anyway, despite some mixed yelp reviews, I think Utopia is definitely worth a try, especially for it clay pots and the nice, family atmosphere!
author: Alan L.

description:
My Clay Pot Rice eating adventure has brought me back to Utopia!!! And its been a while that... I  have eaten here until yesterday which was on a Sunday night and several times I haven eaten lunch here in the past!!! But this is my very first time ever that... I have eaten dinner at Utopia!!! And this time I tried three different kinds of Clay Pot Rice and no I did not eat up all three Clay Pot Rice all by myself... Its because I shared it with my family!!! If you plan on going to Utopia for some Clay Pot Rice you gotta try the Clay Pot Rice at Utopia and just by the smell of the Clay Pot Rice would make you wanna drool over it!!! And just one more more thing that I have to say about Utopia is that the restaurant staff are friendly to us and of course the Clay Pot Rice is really good when it comes to being really hungry!!! I also forgot to mention one last thing besides the Clay Pot Rice if like soup go for the West lake Minced Beef Soup its really good when it comes nice and hot right out of the Kitchen!!!

~ Here are my 3 most favorite Clay Pot Rice list that I really like most at the Utopia Cafe Of The San Francisco Chinatown Area ~

1. MINCED BEEF RICE W/RAW EGG IN CLAY POT

2. CHICKEN W/MUSHROOM RICE IN CLAY POT RICE

3. SALTED FISH & MINCED PORK RICE CLAY POT
author: William B.

description:
Solid food and good value.  I'd stick with the preserved meat claypot over the minced pork and salted fish.  

$20 min for credit card, so if your light eaters, bring cash
author: Larry L.

description:
So the salted fish and minced pork rice in clay pot ($7.95) showed up on 7x7 Big Eat 2014 and here I am. So though I didn't try anything else I feel confident in recommending the clay pots here as their specialty. 

And it's pretty much how it sounds, a clay pot, medium sized, filled with a whole lotta rice and then topped with a patty of meat and some halves of bok choy like vegetable. It will be be like 66-75% rice. At first I was like, what a rip off! Just rice! But no fear, the rice is fabulous. It's not the usual steamed rice you get with Asian food. Someone more informed than I can tell you what kind of rice it was. All I can say is that it was more translucent and glossier than normal rice and it's cooked perfectly in the clay pot with just a little bit of stickiness to help you eat it but still al dente with the individual grains. They give you a small bowl of sauce you pour over the rice - something salty, savory, a little bit soy sauce but a little more of something else (probably not vegetarian is my guess).

One clay pot is enough to feed two people for lunch (or in my case one very pregnant hungry friend).

It takes about 20 minutes (so they say) to cook the clay pots but ours took only 15 min probably? It was 2 pm on a Monday and it wasn't very busy though there were a few other full tables. They bring out a very plain soup to start with - barley, lotus roots, carrots, pork in a home brewed bone broth. Nothing fancy but kinda like what you expect your aunties to make for you at home.

For some reason we were charged an additional 2 x $1.60 for something on the bill. The soup? The tea? I have no idea. Lunch was so cheap and plentiful I didn't complain but if you count your pennies you might want to ask before accepting any extras.

Ambiance: cafeteria style but not dirty/divey.
author: Jean K.

description:
Brunch with my parents and the fiancé 
Coldand rainy Sunday
Free soup - root veggies, pork, carrots, dates - yum - perfect 
Fried chicken wings - delish!
Steam egg with shrimp, mushroom, squid, peas on top - delicate. Definitely order again!
Chinese sausage + duck clay pot - very good but duck a little salty for my flavor
Chicken and ginger clay pot - standard but still tasty
Total: $45 w/o tips
We all loved the food and good change of pace from regular Sunday dim sum in Chinatown
author: PreciousSwt P.

description:
Great authentic Chinese (Cantonese) cooking. Their specialty is the rice clay pots, REALLY delicious. My favorite is the meat patty. 

They serve complimentary "slow cooked" soups with your meal. It's just like home!!

Service is what you should expect at a Chinese restaurant that caters to mostly Chinese locals, i.e. It won't be the best service but it's sufficient.
author: Critic X.

description:
I came here with my friend a couple weeks ago and the food was great! I ordered the lemon chicken was it was juicy and perfectly seasoned. Today I decided to try the sesame salad and it wasn't good at all and that's why I am giving it three stars. Chicken was under seasoned and soggy, lettuce was half cooked. Also, some of the chicken pieces were so small that I mistook them for being lettuce.

I'm not one to complain about price, but portions are on the smaller side for the price. 

My sister got the salt and pepper calamari and it was under seasoned and soggy. It seems everything I get is soggy
author: Jessica L.

description: Food was pretty good and reasonably priced, but the service was the worst I've seen in many years as the waitress openly and rudely demanded more tips at the end. Easily minus 4 stars just based on that.
author: Simon W.

description:
I like there hot pot steam rice when I come to sf with a craving for that.. I love the black bean sauce chinese spareribs hot pot rice with veggies in it. 
when I come with family we order the meal dinner with one any hot pot rice with a plate of daily veggies and a daily steamed fish and daily soup for 30 bucks which I think is a good deal and perfect traditional combo. might not be on the menu in english but sure is in the chinese menu one. if u cant find it just ask them. 
service here is so so sometimes great and sometimes just slow. bathroom is avg better than other resto in china town so no complaint.
author: Alex T.

description:
This place is more of a chinese-chinese food place... authentic, not americanized chinese food - ie. orange chicken, mongolian beef... if you're looking for this... panda express please. :) 

I just read a review below and i wanted to address that first... LOL the guy mentioned 'this might be popular in china, but not here in america'... as a chinese american ... dude thats offensive.. this is authentic chinese food... you're in the HEART of chinatown, san francisco, none the less... *face palm*.. AND you're a yelp elitist... just saying, nothing personal... I guess you wouldn't know any better, because you're amercian ... and these CHINESE american dishes aren't Mcdonald's enough for you. Our bad.  I guess everyone's individual preference is different, so you're entitled to your yelp review. 

Anyway, I'm going to give this place five stars because its really hard to find authentic chinese food in chinatown unless you really know where to go. Everything is sort of touristy. I came here with a group of 15 and we did a family style lunch, we had about 12 dishes. It was great because they brought us downstairs to this disco-ish room... so if you have a large party and dont mind being left a lone for a little while.. go here... haha its fun. Definitely not for any prissy or snobby kids though haha ... its kinda a hole in the wall...and astetically ... not the best hehe . 

dishes I reccomend here... all the clay pots are awesome and the pea pod shoots are really good too.
author: Mish L.

description: Was recommended this place by a chinese resident foot reflexologist nearby. Great chinese food, with a true simple home-cooked  taste of Hong Kong. This is where chinese people eat.
author: Agent W.

description:
Good Prices/ Bad Service.

The other members in my party ordered various clay pot rice dishes. They didn't really appeal to me, so I ordered the Shrimp Wonton Noodle Soup. It was a good price for $4.95, but tasted bland. I also tried the congee, which was also bland.

Service sucked. The waitresses were really rude. When we requested for something, they did not hide their irritation.
author: Helen H.

description: I'm walking by and an elderly Chinese gentleman walks out of the restaurant.  He looks at me, points to the door and says, "good food."  I have a frog hotpot (tastes like Chicken but better).  It's excellent.  Service us businesslike but friendly by the standards of Chinatown. I think I saw the same gentleman going out the door several times; he is right, though -- good food.
author: Charles E.

description:
As a disclaimer: I did visit this place at about 9 PM when the rest of Chinatown was virtually closed, so whereas I would not visit this place again based on my experience, others may have had a much better experience during the day. However, in reality, the experience should be consistent from open to close, so I can't base my review on what might have been.

PRO: One of the few open places open late in Chinatown (a lot of places close around 6 or 7 PM, and Chinatown itself is a ghost town at 9 PM).

SUMMARY: When we walked in we were warmly greeted, seated, provided menus, and then within a few moments after getting settled were asked if we would like anything to drink. Check. Looks like we are on our way to a solid experience. The menu is vast so you should be able to find something.

We ordered the egg roll (vegetarian) as an appetizer and I ordered the Hong Kong beef chow fun, while my girlfriend ordered something else (I can't recall). The egg rolls came out promptly, but were super hot. Like, you might as well be drinking the frying oil hot (though they were not at all dripping with oil). Hot is good - heck of a lot better than cold. But scalding hot - I'd like a warning please. And it's no fun being hungry and being forced to watch your food cool on the plate for 10 min before you can eat it. I'd rather it just be kept in the back until it is close to edible - maybe that's just me.

The main dishes came out while we had barely begun the egg rolls, which, isn't terrible since they were just egg rolls and this is a hole-in-the-wall type place, so I can't dock them for that. But, the meals were equally hot. Had to let those cool for a tad also. My meal was pretty lacking in beef and the entire thing was under seasoned and bland. It was like I got the leftovers from the day, which very well may have been the case.

While we were sitting down eating, the entire staff came out and had a "family meal" next to us. From then on, we received very poor attention. Now, I would not expect this to happen midday, but still, it was annoying in the least.

Good luck!
author: Brett S.

description: Great place. Brought a group of kids here after a tour of haunted Chinatown. They gave us our own space in the basement. Super accommodating.  Thank you!!
author: Corinne S.

description: Best Homestyle cooking in Chinatown!!The chicken wings are delicious. The clay pots and fried tofu are a must try. If you want great food at a great price, it's a must if you come to SF.
author: Jecina N.

description:
I go there for their clay pot rice, cooked traditional style.  Takes 30 minutes to make so order it when you sit down, or for large groups make reservation and order the food in advance.   The kitchen isn't that huge so sometimes things can be slow. The price is reasonable for what you are getting.  

 Yes, it is annoying that the price on the display window is lower than the price in the menu inside.
author: Kenneth L.

description:
The service is mediocre at best. If you come with two people they expect you to at least order two things.

The clay pot rice was a good size. It fed the two of us. The rice was crispy on the bottom.
author: Bobby C.

description:
Sometimes it can be a roulette table when scoping out a restaurant in China Town, in the late evening. Happened upon Utopia.  Please skip to "Our Dinner" below to avoid social commentary. 

Utopia is a lofty name for a restaurant, and for some it may be accurate depiction of this joint.. Sat near a table of maybe 10 folks who appeared to be from Kansas and had some exposure to Chinese cuisine. By their loud comments, they thought they were in Utopia. "Martha did you taste that beeeeef and brocolie? " and "thats the best egg fooooo younnng I've had ..." It was an amazing thing when one of the diners offered instruction to the server as to how to serve one of the dishes, when it was quite apparent that no Chinese restaurant would hire her to do anything.

Our Dinner:

Fried tofu squares (salt / pepper) - a simple dish and crisp shells  
pea sprouts (w/ garlic)- tender and properly prepared 
steamed fish - fresh fish ! black bean sauce was not overwhelming
seafood/veggie hot pot - took a while to prepare, but worth the wait
Beef chow fun: great. beef tender and noodles properly cooked (always get this dish "dry" so that it is not drowned in an unidentifiable brown sauce)

Food: Overall it was a good dinner, liked each dish
Pricing: Inline w/ the food - fairly priced
Service: Inline w/ the type of restaurant
author: Matsuo U.

description: Food was amazing! Probably some of the best walnut shrimp I've had in a long time. Staff was super friendly. It was also awesome to come in and see my grandmothers picture on the wall. Will def come back again.
author: Kay M.

description:
Ok this time I came with my cousin and a friend, we were hungry!! Ordered up the following (Pictures are also posted):
Wet Beef Chow Fun: Yum just how I like it no fuss, chow fun, wet yummy sauce, beef and bok choy, perfect.
Highlight of the night: Hot and Sour Soup! I've never had it so thick and flavorful in my life! Best hot and sour soup I've ever had! Extra star for that!
Beef Wonton Noodle soup, eh ok
Fuckin Fried Rice or is it Fujin fried rice? I don't know, it was good, that's all I know.
Then we got the complimentary sweet soup at the end.
It was great service, the waitress said she asked the cook to make us extra soup because we said we liked it alot! She made sure all the food tasted good and checked up on us frequently. Oh and I have to say again, they have a magician there some nights, WHAT! a Magician in a Chinese restaurant?? Unheard of!
author: Karen T.

description: It's embarrassing that as a local San Franciscan we don't get to chinatown much. There are some real gems. And, there are some real dogs. That's why I'm writing this review. This is a gem. We went with a group of about 30 people - we had a board meeting of a national organization here in the city - and the service was great and the food was fantastic. We were served a spinning buffet of fried fish - not a drop of oil! - walnut prawns, fried rice, spare ribs and a few excellent vegetables. The servers brought beers and were helpful and courteous.
author: joan g.

description:
Not bad. I came for the claypot rice and was disappointed because the rice just wasn't crispy enough for me. I prefer House of Claypot on Clement where almost every morsel is crispy - that is the best part about claypot rice after all. 

The ingredients and flavors in the claypot rice were good, though (we had the salted fish with pork and the Chinese sausage/duck ones). We liked how they gave the sauce on the side. 

Chicken jook and sautéed pea shoots were solid. Friendly, fast service. Very homey - nice to get complimentary soup and tong sieu. I might come back to try other homestyle dishes but probably not the claypot.
author: Melinda C.

description: As far as I'm concerned this is authentic Hong Kong style. It's set up as a low key place with modest interior decor. This restaurant is not set up for tourists which some Chinatown restaurants do. I really liked everything I had including yang chow fried rice, cucumber soup and some fish. It can get busy at lunchtime because of its growing reputation. Prices are also lower than what you would expect.
author: Edward P.

description: Food is BLAND, NO TASTE whatsoever, had to add condiments myself. And they charged gratuity after tax. the lady waitress is rude. Bad service.
author: Windy K.

description:
The clay pot rice is extremely good. My father, who insists he doesn't eat much sure down that baby fast. And for a little old man with a bad arm, he sure scraped all the rice off the clay pot! Go dad, go! 

What attracted me to Utopia was the wide range of menu selections. There is something for every person in your party. But I had my eye on clay pot rice. If cooked right and with the right ingredients, your tummy will smile. 

Dad and I ordered the Chinese sausage, preserved duck and I think liver sausage clay pot rice. Keep in mind, it will take approximately 25 minutes or more to cook. In the mean time, I ordered wonton noodles to share with dad. Noodles were al dente, broth was okay and wonton was better than expected. I wouldn't say it's equivalent to Hong Kee on Kearny street but it did the trick. I would order the wonton again.

Back to the rice, it came piping hot with a rice bowl of soy sauce on the side. Dad added the sauce to the rice and waited about 5 minutes before serving. Yes, it was delish!! All the flavor came together perfectly. I would return just for that all by myself. 

The wonderful thing about Utpoia is that they offer 2hrs free parking at Portmouth Square parking lot. I think there is a 40.00 minimum but not sure on that. 

Like most Asian eateries, the bathroom is not the most cleanest but this one was not bad...at least there were TP and soap.
author: Jessica L.

description:
Top notch! Great service! Came with a group of 11ppl. 
Asked to bring their specials, everything was very delicious. Service was fast and very attentive. Owner stopped by and said hi, it was a very nice touch.
author: Natasha S.

description:
Service - 5 stars
Food - 4 Stars

After a frustrating 50 minute wait at Szechuan Cuisine Uncle Cafe, we decided to come here. OH MY GOODNESS, what a contrast in service.

As we walked through the door, a nice lady greeted and said it will be few minutes before your table is ready. Less than two minutes go by and we were seated. WIN

A waitress immediately brought us some tea and menus. WIN

After ordering, there was a complimentary soup. WIN

We ordered garlic chicken wings for out appetizer. It was crispy on the outside and very moist inside. WIN

Since they are know for their clay pots, we ordered the braised tofu and minced pork with rice, both clay pots. WIN

They waitress checked to see if we were doing OK during our dinner. WOW, that never happens at a Chinese restaurant. WIN

Since I do not stuff myself when I eat (just satiated) we had leftovers. WIN

Our overall experience was good. This is a very family friendly restaurant. WIN

They take credit cards. BIG WIN
author: Tony N.

description:
The wonton soup was better than the clay pot chicken.  Found it to be very blah and pretty much a let down.  Wish I had seen the review on the best hot n sour soup ever here as I should have gotten that!
Prices are cheap though, portions large and service is friendly.  If it is like the day we were there though, prepare to wait a really long time.
author: Alexandra C.

description:
I've been looking for a HK clay pot place in Chinatown and FINALLY found one. Their claypots are definitely comparable to the ones in HK. :) The chinese sausage and spareribs ones are definitely the best.

I am a fan and will be back!
author: Joyce M.

description: So me and about 5 friends couldn't decide on a place to eat. We were walking in Chinatown and this woman approached us I'm going to call her 'Ann' because I didn't know her name. So we walked about a block following Ann and we walked in not the greatest attraction but the food let me tell you!!!!!! Everything was soooo good!!!! The beef stew wonton noodle soup, general chic, sesame chicken, Mongolian beef everything!!!
author: Melissa T.

description:
Just had dinner here tonight. The service was very good and the price was reasonable.
This place has been here a long time and we came here because our other restaurant choices had many many people waiting for tables because of Mother's Day.  We have not visited this place for many years. This is definitely not Hong Kong style cuisine, it is mediocre Cantonese food.
author: D. C.

description: I love the food. Huge variety of clay pots.
author: Lee D.

description: Got the wrong food, ate it anyways. Was super bland. Don't recommend.  There was gratuity added in the bill, I begrudgingly paid it.
author: Alec T.

description:
Went here yesterday with my mom while waiting for our ghost tour to begin. We ordered the Mongolian beef and the chicken fried rice. The beef was very good. It was spicy but not too spicy and very tender. The fried rice was pretty disgusting. The grains were not fully cooked having a hard texture and a pale appearance. The chicken was boiled left over parts. I would never order that again. The service was only okay. The waitress was short spoken and did not come back to check on us. 
I would probably not come back here again. The Mongolian beef was good but not good enough to make me want to return.
author: Alicia V.

description:
I came here with my family and we got the Salted Fish Chicken Fried Rice, the Fried Chicken Wings, Curry Beef Stew Clay Pot and Beef Stew with Wonton Noodle Soup. My favorite was the Chicken Wings, they were a tad bit salty, but they were super crispy and juicy :) Another notable mention is the fried rice, which was very tasty :) The server was nice too.

Only problem is the layout of the place, but that's not a huge problem :)
author: Amanda L.

description:
I had to pick a restaurant in Chinatown using the iPhone Yelp! app, and ended up on this one.  Now I've gone there, and I'm unconvinced that it stands out in any way from the other Chinese restaurants teeming around it.

One really great thing about it was that they offered a fantastic deal on a veggie dinner spread, if you ordered it for two people.  $10 for 2 veggie egg rolls, 2 bowls of vegetable soup, mu shu vegetables, fried tofu with mushrooms, veggie fried rice, tea, and fortune cookies.

The only thing was, the food wasn't that great.  The egg rolls were, as was the tofu-- amazing flavor and so silky! And the soup was definitely not lacking in vegetables.  But the mu shu was pretty bland, it soaked through the pancakes immediately, ripping them.  Plus my fiance found a rock (!) in his!  He almost chipped his tooth... Luckily, he still would have been able to enjoy the mushrooms in the tofu dish, which he found slimy (but agree to disagree there; I enjoyed them!)

We also appreciated that they validated the parking in the garage down on Kearny Street-- a free two hours-- if you spend $30!
author: Allison M.

description:
When you walk on one of San Francisco's Chinatown's historic alley, you actually feel like a part of Chinese History. I can elaborate all day from my grandparents taking my siblings and I to hang out at one of many associations listening to Old-school Chinese Opera and play mah-jongg, to assisting my parents in grocery shopping-duties in my beloved Chinatown.   

It did seems like yesterday when that happen. And currently, I have the responsibility of carrying the torch and take my daughter with me to walk around the historic Waverly Alley for an early dinner. We all know that history is over and the future is tomorrow.  But like yesterday, today and beyond, Waverly Place is still one of the most historic and "dirtiest" alleys in San Francisco. 

Utopia Cafe has been opened maybe twenty years and amazingly the restaurant is one of the newest businesses in the block. As a result, there isn't too much history of this restaurant. But I can tell you that this bright-light and hole in the wall cafe serves your conventional Chinese cuisines. 

I had a craving for a clay pot meal, so my daughter and I split an ordered of Curry Chicken in the steamy Clay Pot. For $8.00, the Clay pot's content contains the bits of chicken meat, sliced onions and peppers in a thick and mild curry sauce. With just about everything you wanted in a meal, the clay pot was comforting and tolerable enough for my daughter and I to enjoy. 

We also split an order of Salt and Pepper Wings for $5.00. We get ten pieces of the crispy wings and they are crispy and tasty. I just found out that the restaurant is currently having a special on the wings for $2.00. Just mentioned to the helpful and friendly waitresses that you are and proudly a Yelper and you will get those wings for the special price. 

Our meal also comes with tea, house-soup and warm red-bean soup for dessert. The waitress were very vigilant and assisted our needs when needed. 

I paid our meal in cash and credit cards are also accepted. There is also a Yelp-sticker and various awards on the door too. 

Now that is your Chinatown History lesson from me. It's also free too.
author: Matt G.

description:
Had a walk around Chinatown during Chinese New Year and a woman off the street offered us a flyer to come into the cafe along with a menu. Said that we're walking around but will check the cafe out.

Found the cafe by chance.. It had been a long day, sun was coming down, we were all hungry.

Walked in a nearly empty cafe of four.. Sat ourselves down and ordered hot tea. Flicking through the menu, Vegetarian options were few, but I'm not one to complain.

Waiting for our waitress to write up our orders..My eyes started scanning round the room and it's floors.. Found INCHES by my foot what looked like a single solid grain of black rice..

Only it wasn't..

Yeah.

Asked for the $2 check for our tea which I thankfully didn't touch and left.
author: Ace T.

description: I love their general shrimp so tasty and their house soup is so good. My dad always took me here and since he passed away I still come here because I love the warm welcoming of their food.
author: Kaida C.

description:
My friends and I were in Chinatown during the new year festival on Saturday.  We were looking for a place to eat and we stumbled upon this restaurant.  We were tired of thinking of where to eat so we decided to give this place a try.  

The services here were ok, good enough.  The food wise, just mediocre.  Nothing special or anything.  The food was a little bland for me.  I got the beef stew wonton noodle soup.  It was only ok.  The prices are pretty decent.  

What sucks was that they ran out of chow fun in the early afternoon.  My friend wanted that too.  He ended up having to order something else.  His order turned out not too appealing.  His dish suppose to come with green onions but he only got one and half tiny onions.  What the heck was that?  Might as well just not put any!  It was very disappointing as my friend likes green onions too.  We are not the type of people that likes to complain so we just left it alone.  We will not come back here again.
author: Susan B.

description: The claypot rice was ok. But their customer service very bad, the waitress is servicing with frown face and demanded certain amount of tips to be made even we are not satisfied with the service provided. Recommend to go for other restaurant for claypot rice. Not a pleasant experience for just a claypot rice.
author: Lim Y.

description:
Not bad.

When I see that places offer clay pot I usually think it would take forever for the food to come out. The waitress said it would take 15mins and I was sold! The food kinda took longer than that, maybe even 25mins which kinda destroyed a star. When the food finally came out, it was pretty good. What I love is the crispy rice around the pot and it is hard to really perfect that and they somewhat did and i was happy. I was kinda surprised how small the bowls were compared to other clay pot places especially for $8. Something like that would kill it for me. I would come back....
author: Jade L.

description:
No stars what so ever! 
I was stopped by this girl promoting the a special that was being offered at this restaurant. I had high hopes about this place because I was stopped by this girl before in the past. Of course at that time it was a different restaurant. 
Anyway, the service started off well. It was quite and not too crowded. This was on a Saturday after 5pm. The food however was luke warm. I was starving so at the time nothing really mattered. 
So then I paid the check and proceeded to finish my hot tea and read my fortune cookie. A couple walked in and not even a minute later after I had paid the check and left the tip, the same waitress told me to get up and sit over on the waiting bench by the entrance door. She took away the tea I was drinking in the process!!! How rude!!! I let that one pass. I took back the tip and left with a grin on my face.
author: Philip V.

description: Don't know why this places gets anything lower than a 4 star. Food is good, price is right!
author: Andrew I.

description:
Came here because babe and his friends really wanted clay rice pots (and because they had to run errand in ct). 
Since I'm not a big fan of ordering clay pots since my parents make it too often at home, I ordered the trusty old beef chow fun which I always happen to crave. 

The beef chow fun was quite oily, but it was tasty nonetheless and I enjoyed every bite as I devoured it (with a few wandering forks from friends stabbing at my plate here and there).  I totally wouldn't mind coming back for more of this dish. 

Of the clay pots I tried I think I enjoyed was definitely the Chicken with mushroom rice clay plot because the chicken was just so soft and juicy unlike I would imagine. (I wanted to steal a few more pieces of my friend, but then they wouldn't have anything left but rice.. lol) 

I think babe had one of the minced beef or pork clay rice which was still good, but it was exactly home cooking and it's not exactly what I want when I eat out.
author: Harriet W.

description:
This unique bold signboard " Utopia " just caught my eye (how could it not?) and here in SF Chinatown? I would associate this name with Greek at my first thought and I peep in to see this little cafe pretty much crowded at 6:30 pm in the evening.That's a good sign to try and why not? 

This is what I picked for the appetizer to start with is the fried chicken wings and toufu cubes and a glass of beer for an ideal start. Awesomely addicting is their pork belly with preserved vegetables and their steamed salted fish with mince pork to accompany with steamed white rice. I am one that is not too crazy over any meat dishes due to the gamely smell but with this pork that its simmer for hours I was told, is simply to-die-for ... the flavor with the rice ..... yummylicious! mmmmm! Add a side dish of stir fry green fresh vegetables with garlic, you have a perfect meal be it for lunch or dinner! 

Highly suggest going with a foursome or six so you can order more and do it family style! Oh and can invite me too!

OK the next question you would ask if Parking is easily available? Its not always easy to find a place that has its own lot but finding a space is never an issue at the nearby parking lot building. I can tell you its worth the trip and park! 

You won't be disappointed with my choices to start with. Its a " come-back-able " cafe I would back again to try their other dishes not forgetting the must have " Clay pot " chicken!

See, when the unexpected arrive in front of you, go with your heart and you will find a gem! You don't try you won't know!

I love SF
Lady Ann
author: Lady Ann B.

description:
For the price it is good enough, it's cheap compared to the higher end Chinese restaurants which is a perk but last time I went the food was sub par. 

We initially ordered the sesame chicken and the seafood clay rice pot, and were not quite satisfied with either of the entrees. The  sesame chicken had a pinch of sesame seeds and the chicken wasn't crispy because it was drenched in the sauce. You would think it couldn't get worse, but the chicken wasn't even hot when it initially arrived. The seafood rice pot was "okay" nothing too special.

I've had better here so that's the only reason I'm really giving them 3 stars...
author: Amy S.

description: Good value for money on a late night if you are in this part of town. The claypots were quite flavorful and filling.
author: Andy L.

description: On the last Wednesday or Thursday night of every month (you need to check as it does vary) from 7:30-9:30 pm they have open mic night and some of the city's finest musicians are on hand to perform. Totally hidden gem and amazing evening. Next one scheduled for June 26! See you there!
author: Justin Y.

description: If you want authentic Chinese cuisine, this is the place to go.  The menu is large and every dish we had tasted delicious.  We were the only non Chinese diners there, and to me that speaks volumes about the food quality, excellent.
author: Shane A.

description: First the lady who stopped us on the street to get us to come in took us four blocks out of our way to get there. They had two other tables (of customers) and it took almost 20 minutes for someone to get our drink order. When our drinks came the glasses were 3/4 empty already. The service was terrible and when we finally got our food it was nothing great. The bathrooms were disgusting. And our glasses and silverware weren't completely clean. It was not worth the four block walk and when we went to pay our bill was almost $20 more than anticipated because they added in their tip (which wasn't marked on the bill or mentioned) they weren't going to tell us we were just shocked that our bill was so high and asked why. So that led us to believe they weren't going to tell us and let us tip them twice! I will never go back again and do NOT recommend this place to anyone.
author: Vickie M.

description:
I will say the food was excellent. However the service was horrible. The waitress was super rude! Chow Fun on the menu is what drew me into this place. When we sat down to order, they said they were out of Chow Fun. 
On top of that, the waitress tried to add her own $10 tip to our bill. We said heck no!!!!!!! Also, the waitress charged my card for the total amount of the bill. I wrote down what I wanted to charge on my card!! I check my bank acct. today to and they double charged me!!!
author: Adriana C.

description:
Total hidden gem for those who don't mind eating in less than fabulous atmospheres. The place is tucked away in a quiet street of Chinatown and is quite simple in design.

The one thing you have to get here is the clay pot rice. I'd recommend getting it with chicken and mushrooms. It takes 20-25 minutes to make since it's freshly prepared but it's totally worth the wait. This is what all the local Chinese people know this place is known for.
author: Victor W.

description:
I came here twice and i just love it!

i really like their clay pots because u rarely see places do this anymore. It takes 20 min because they actually cook it with the clay pot unlike some places where they just put it in a clay pot and serve it. The only thing Im not as happy about is that it seems like the temperature to cook it isn't high enough so the smell and taste of the rice isn't as strong as traditionally making it. 

But i do like the place because its a pretty clean places to eat at in chinatown
author: Angela L.

description:
Came back for 'boh jai fan' again -- was craving it badly! Got the ground pork pattie and salty fish one again to share with the family, but this time, also got some garlic pea sprouts, shrimp and pork wontons, salt and pepper tofu. 

Everything was delicious, although this time, the crust on the bottom of the claypot rice wasn't as scorched as the last time I ate here.

I thought service is pretty good for Chinatown, but again, that's because I speak Cantonese, and they seem to react better than say, English or Mandarin.

If you spent $30 or more you also get 2 hours validated parking at Portsmouth Square Garage -- so that's even more reason to dine here.

Everyone loved it!!
author: Anita L.

description: Stumble upon here because a girl was passing out flyers . My family got the family dinner which came with soup, sweet and sour pork chops, chicken with mushrooms, steamed fish , and dessert. When you spend $30 you can get a plate of fried chicken for $1. I think you get free parking for 2 hours if you buy a minimum amount of food of $39. Taste of the food was good ad had a home style feel to it. If there was MSG in the cooking , there was a little amount since I didn't feel bloated or sleepy afterwards. Food was also not very oil which is not common in Chinese cooking:) overall 4 stars.
author: Tina N.

description: Good food, duck was very good and not expensive. Th staff are friendly and served really fast. It could be a bit more cleaner.
author: Farhad V.

description:
I hope you realize that Utopia is the name coined by Sir Thomas More for an ideal society possessing a seemingly perfect socio-politico-legal system. Now I'm not sure if they have achieved that level of nirvana since I was stuck in the corner of this compact place with no room for my bulbous body to squeeze through. Does that sound like Utopia? It sounds more like Dystopia if you ask me...or maybe Anti-Fatopia!

This bare-bones restaurant is located on the surprisingly non-congested alley where the redoubtable Uncle's Cafe is on the corner. Even though they have the standard Cantonese dishes on the menu, I came here for the famous claypots. I took a look at the faded 2003 San Francisco Magazine cover (see my photo) they have framed in the window, which spotlights the $6.95 Cuttlefish and Minced Pork Claypot as #34 among the top 125 best things to eat in the city. OK, that's for me.

First up was a cup of warm, nondescript soup (see my photo with the appealing reflection of the fluorescent lights). Then came the huge claypot topped with lots of tender Chinese broccoli (see my photo). Underneath was a big patty of pork and cuttlefish chopped up into a burger-like consistency, all of it resting on a whole lotta rice. Naturally the best part of the rice is the crusty part on the sides of the bowl. I have to admit I liked it a lot, though I kinda wished it was a fried rice to break up the carbs a bit. There was enough for two people, but I was having a bad day, OK? Don't judge me.

FOOD - 4 stars...hearty claypots...but hey, you don't get to keep the bowl, dammit
AMBIANCE - 2.5 stars...lunch room central at a senior center
SERVICE - 3 stars...they work in Utopia...they must be happy, right?
TOTAL - 4 stars...oh what the hell, we'll keep it at 4 stars for the mutha-sized claypot
author: Ed U.

description:
I came in with a friend to conquer 7x7s big eats item: salted fish and minced pork rice in clay pot.  It sounds delicious and I was excited. I'm sorry to say, it was not. The clay pot wasn't done right...the rice was mushy and there wasn't a single crispy cooked piece to be found in the pot. I love clay pot, but this wasn't it. There wasn't much flavor to it and it wasn't done right. My friend had a large bowl of soup and stated that it was too bland and felt like the things inside were added to the soup after they were already cooked..not cooked inside the broth. Weird. 

Also, I stood up to pay while my friend sat and paid in cash. As I was paying the woman kept saying to me "you have to tip" and I told her that we would. My friend was planning to leave the tip. I went back and sat at the table to finish my tea and the woman came and took all of our plates of our table and banged the table and said "YOU MUST TIP!!" and just kept repeating "tip tip tip" while hitting the table. We were both shocked--as we hadn;t gotten up or left the restaurant yet, and we were fully planning on tipping her--cash left upon the table as we exit--as per usual. It was a very strange experience. My friend ended up pulling 5 dollars out and handing it to her and then we scooted out. I've never experienced anything quite like that. 

The food wasn't great, but the service was terrible. We won't be back.
author: Lacy R.

description: Friend and I were looking for a good Chinese restaurant. This lady came up to us with flyers of her restaurant. So we decided to give it a try. The food was good. The restaurant was pretty clean but the service wasn't great. After the meal the waitress gave us the bill and she kept repeating "tip" "tip" "tip". She would not leave our table until she saw that I put a tip on the receipt. She was hovering and I just thought that was rude. Over all the food was good but I would not come back again.
author: Beatriz Z.

description: A small hole in the wall tucked away on a tiny street of Chinatown. 3.5 stars, only because the place makes you feel like it's cold and dirty. The food here is bomb though- I'm Chinese and this is no Panda Express. They are known for their clay pots, so you gotta try one of those. All the flavors I've tried are equally delicious, I prefer the chicken clay pot, but the sausage one is their most famous. For dinner, they also have the option of ordering 3 entrees for a good price- I would recommend the fish with scallions and ginger. The pork and preserved egg congee is legit here too! Don't get their "Family Dinner" with kung pao chicken and eggrolls-- that's asking for it to be bad.
author: Jessica L.

description:
I can't tell you how many times I've ordered something just to regret it completely because I know I should be ordering something else.  However, I like to judge a Chinese restaurant by its wonton noodle soup, and I kind of wish I didn't.

Sara P. and I headed here in search of good Chinese food.  It was recommended by a few of my coworkers, who said the clay pot was really good.  Not that I didn't have this in mind, but I was just in the mood for wontons, and if it'd been good, it would've totally made my day because after our office move, Hon's is now like two blocks down a steep hill for me, and walking up that hill on a full stomach is really no bueno.  Utopia, on the other hand, is on a flat walk of Waverly directly across from my office.  It had potential.

The menu is pretty extensive, with different types of veggies, clay pots, noodles, noodle soups, meat, porridge (jook/congee) and rice dishes.  Prices start at $2.50 for a plain bowl of porridge, and goes up around $8 for most other things.  I had my eye on the minced meat clay pot, but the wontons took over my brain, so I ordered the shrimp wonton noodle soup for $4.95.

It was okay.  At most, it was a 3-star meal.  There were 5 wontons that were too hard and too densely packed into the wrapper for me, and there was a sort of funky taste to it, like they didn't add some sort of seasoning or whatnot (maybe the pork they used was bad?  I hope not, since I didn't get sick yet).  The noodles were on par with Hon's, and it's the dry-ish curly thin noodles that remind me of over-permed, over-stressed hair.  The broth, with a few shakes of salt, was good.

I think I'll leave my experience at 3 stars for now, since the service was mediocre (again, it's a Chinese restaurant so it's not like I was expecting my chair to be pulled out for me) and prices and quality were just okay compared to some of the other restaurants around the area (Hon's, New HK Menu).

Oh, and if you go between 2:30 and 5 (I think) they have "afternoon tea time" specials, but they were all in Chinese so I couldn't understand what they were serving.  Boo.

I'm totally down to come back here and try out all the other dishes and their tapioca teas (it looks like a place that would be good).  Oh, and the other thing that kind of is awesome: they accept credit cards.  Not sure if there's a minimum of any sort since we paid cash, but at least for bigger parties it won't be a problem.
author: Tori S.

description:
The food: LOVE IT.  Quite possibly the best Chinese food I've ever eaten.  FIVE STARS.

The service: uh... weird.  Maybe it's a cultural difference thing.  Dunno.  In any event, what lacks in warm-fuzzies doesn't transfer over to ignored requests or rudeness or anything.  I get water refills and extra napkins and a box for leftovers.  They're patient when I ask questions about the menu (full disclosure: I'm not Chinese.  Surprising, I know).  So it's a draw: keeping it at five stars.

I wish I didn't know that when I order soup they *microwave* it for service.  Minus 3 stars.

But then add one lost star back for the sexiest, greenest greens I have ever seen on a plate at a hole-in-the-wall Chinese restaurant.

And add another star back for *not* dousing those greens in MSG or in an obscene amount of oil during preparation.

And another for your accommodation of my request for SO much oyster sauce to go with my mu shu order (and the mu shu is diiiiiviiiiiiinnnnnne).  Five stars.

It's always a good sign when the restaurant is packed.  And it is.  Every time I come in.  Oh!  And they're open on Christmas (or at least, have been in the past), so you can go get your culturally-insensitive cliche on should you also fall into one of the faith categories that means you don't really do Christmas.

...dizzam: is it time for a meal yet?  I dun gone made myself hungry for summa Utopia's menu!!
author: Rachel S.

description:
I am fairly adventurous when it comes to cuisine, but this hole in the wall Chinese spot is not for Americans. Ordered the beef stew claypot and it was all tendons, fat, and grissle. This might be popular in China, but not here in America. It was simply gross to me. Made my stomach turn. We sent it back for Mongolian beef, which was extremely salty to the point of being inedible. I was hungry so I ate it anyway. Green beans were overseasoned too.

Left feeling sick and regretful.
author: Brian C.

description: Fantastic food.  Must order in advance their famous their " sticky rice chicken".... Sound spelling Its sticky rice with all kinds of meat and coated with a crispy shell..... Worth coming .... Check out their other dishes ......Outstanding seafood too.  A hidden gem in Chinatown.
author: Erwin W.

description:
In my utopia, I would live in a mansion made of rainbows, have a pet unicorn, and have food from Utopia Cafe to feast on EVERY. SINGLE. DAY!!!!!! :D

Hmm this cafe is so tasty! Definitely go for the clay pot/rice in a clay pot dishes!! My friends and I opted to share the Sizzling Chicken Clay Pot, the Sparerib Rice in a Clay Pot, and pickled pig's feet! Everything was EXCELLENT! All the meat was tender and not chewy at all! I've gotten spareribs at other places and sometimes it's just gristle and bleg.
Know that the dishes under the Clay Pot Platter do NOT include rice, so be sure to order some rice. Or you can be like us and get a rice in a clay pot dish!

The service pretty much sucks, but it's Chinatown, so my standards weren't very high to begin with. Very reasonable prices! Complimentary soup!!

I will definitely be back...see if my review update bumps them up to 5 stars! :)
author: Kei H.

description: Sweet sour soup is great for lunch.  The lunch specials are good but the chicken is mostly "parts" - if ur expecting chicken breast in your king pao u will be disappointed.
author: Ric P.

description:
One of my favorite Chinese restaurants. The rice clay pots are very good, make sure you get one of them. I usually get the spareribs one and a chicken and mushroom one. Their congee is also quite good - they put in dried bean curd like my dad makes it - which makes the congee silky smooth. Their noodle (beef chow fun/chow mein) dishes are good, but if I have time I always order family style dishes here. On two recent occasions I've gotten:
chicken wings- delicious! perfectly cooked and not oily.
clams with black bean sauce- plumb and juicy
yu choy with garlic - good flavor
sweet/sour filet - nice outer batter around the fish with just the right amount of sweet/sour sauce
steamed egg 3 way - my son devours the whole dish practically by himself.

They validate parking if you spend over a certain amount. It used to be $20, then $30, now it might be closer to $40, but don't quote me on the amount. 

The restaurant has now become a well known tourist destination so prepare for waits on peak days/nights.
author: Dom L.

description: Small place, could use some love and attention but the food was good. The service was friendly.  Generous portions...I had leftover for 2 days.
author: Jovita E.

description: Food was expensive for what it was. The house chow me in had noodles that you would find in a salad. There was something in it that tasted spoiled I literally had to spit in my napkin. Nasty. But the black bean chow fun was amazing.  The general chicken was a small portion but really good. Service was ok place was ok as far as cleanliness.
author: Dawn D.

description: Great tasting, authentic Chinese food. We got the 3 entree plus soup combo- claypot eggplant, claypot beef brisket, and stir fried green beans. Everything was delicious and affordable. The dinner also included green bean dessert. Very fast service on a busy Sunday. Would eat here again!
author: Theresa M.

description: Food is authentic Chinese.  Clay pot rice was a little burnt but still delicious.  Customer service needs to improve.  They received a delivery and one of the waitress openly argued with the delivery man right in the dining room for all diners to see.  She was loud and it went on for a while.  I also observed a lady paying for her friend's meal (sitting at another table), and the friend came over and thanked her.  The lady then told a  waitress to inform her friend she had paid the bill and the tips so he won't be paying tips again.   The waitress said ok. I watched her walking towards the man's table, expecting her to deliver the message.  But she walked straight pass the table.  I guess she wanted the double tips from the man.
author: Stella A.

description:
Came here for dinner on Friday evening and ordered a clay pot rice. It comes in one size only! Not super cheap Chinese food but they seated us quickly and there was free soup. 

The rice was not stuck/burnt to the clay pot at all! But their soy sauce for the rice was pretty good. 

I like The Clay Pot House on Clement more.
author: Anita T.

description: Stopped in for lunch as we walked through Chinatown. My family and I found the food to be bland and unflavorful. We also thought that food was too tender and a bit overcooked. They brought food out as if was ready and not all at once (I didn't mind this except that is slightly uncomfortable to have food while others at your table don't). We had to ask multiple times for our drinks. Also, the bathroom had two dumpsters it which made it seem unhygienic.
author: Madison W.

description: What a rip off. I paid $10 for some shitty beef chow fun. Not worth it. They give very little too. I can go to other places for better, cheaper and more food.
author: Peter N.

description:
the salted fish and minced pork made it to this year's 7x7 big eats list so i had to come try it. not sure if i came on an off day but you can barely taste the salted fish! it was just a pork patty with two tiny pieces of salted fish on top. i know the clay pots come with the soy sauce you can pour over but i dont like to drench my food with it.

ive also had the black bean spareribs with bok choy clay pot that's always a favorite of mine. just wished there was more meat of the spareribs and more spareribs in general then there is rice.

not the cleanest of places and it's pretty small and gets crowded at lunch but it's a pretty decent place for clay pot combinations with fair prices
author: Katherine C.

description: So here I am because this place showed up on 7x7 because of the salted fish and minced pork clay pot. I thought the dish was just ok, the rice on the bottom of the claypot wasn't as crunchy as I expected and the service was mediocre, we were seated right away and given menus but we asked for water and it took us asking like 3times before they brought us any water. Overall experience, a typical chinese  restaurant with meh service.
author: Nancy L.

description: I went on a trip with my school and we came here and I guess the location got moved for the ghost tour? Idk but I didn't enjoy this at all. Neither did my group of 50  I don't recommend.
author: Leslie R.

description: What a colossal disappointment!  They used to have the best won ton soup in town.  I don't know what happened but it was horrible! Pot stickers were doughy and tasteless. Chicken salad was a mound of wilted lettuce with a few tiny shreds of chicken.  Never again!
author: Susan L.

description: Great food here, portion was very generous. Pot stickers were huge! Price is fair and I was satisfied with the quality of their food. 4 star only because of cleanliness.
author: Gilbert A.

description:
Very clean restaurant, especially given the fact that it's in China town! We went with a group of 6 and most of the food we ordered was pretty good! Here are my recommendations on what to get and what not to get based off of what we ordered....
What was good: Sweet and Sour Pork with fried rice. Omg. The fried rice is amazing. So so so good. Order it. Generals chicken. Super good!!! Kind of like sweet and sour, but not. It was way good!! 
What was bad: Chicken curry claybowl. Not good, unless you love love a whole meal of curry. The chicken was bad too. And the beef soup. Don't do it. Just bland flavor. 
Another problem we had was that my food took a half hour longer to get out than everyone else's... I got the claybowl. Not worth the wait. 
The fried rice made this place worth going back to!
author: Celsie S.

description:
It's cool to eat here.
Tourist or locals.
**** any clay pot with rice on the bottom cooked just a little bit crispy
author: Cee G.

description:
yeah, this place is probably not that clean.  oh well.

just get the claypot rice dishes.  i wouldn't get the salted fish (holy shit it's too salty and too fishy) but the minced pork and rice was pretty good, so just get the other stuff.
author: Jeffry C.

description: Salt & Pepper Chicken wings are yummy! The 2 clay pots we ordered were mediocre. One was chicken & one was beef, I wouldn't order this again. Staff was really nice which is always an extra star in my book.
author: Jackie D.

description: Came here to eat with my boyfriend's mom and her friend that owns the place. Service was great - maybe because I spoke Cantonese with the waitresses and the owner was around. We came here for dinner - ordered beef chow fun, which had too many bean sprouts for my taste, but their soup was very tasty! I want to return and try their Clay Pot items since it seems to be popular. I also had the honey walnut shrimp which was decent. Their veggies are tasty as well :) A small shop, but authentic & delicious Chinese cuisine.
author: Amanda C.

description: I had the stewed beef noodles - the beef was tenderized and the texture was a little too soft to feel like regular meat. The broth was tasty but nowhere near being a stew. The noodles were a little hard as well. The vegetables weren't cleaned and there was a stalk with black stuff on it. However, it was still good to have a bowl of hot noodles on a chilly day.
author: Heather C.

description:
*CAN'T USE CARDS FOR BILLS UNDER $20*
