Our group of 6 was wandering around SF and we got hungry SO we decided to try this place. It's one of many in the area with ladies coming out to attract people into the business. It's a fairly small place, but we were seated quickly at a nice circular table perfect for our group. We didn't have to wait at all for our waiter to take our order, and although there was some confusion, everything got placed without problem, and with separate checks to boot! Our food arrived pretty quickly, and everything was delicious. We got the Curry chicken clay pot, orange peel chicken, general chicken, lobster with noodles, and dumplings. The only negatives of our experience were: My friend got the drink he ordered WAY late. . . like near the end of the meal. But more frustrating was the fact that we were only told when our checks came that we couldn't use card for bills under $20. . . should have had cash, but also would have liked to know this ahead of time.
author: Charizard B.

description: Such an awesome find amongst a ton of eating options in Chinatown. Had the Hong Kong style beef chow fun and duck with Chinese sausage clay pot. Both were incredible and fair priced. Menu is huge and mostly in mandarin which makes me feel like I found a legit spot. Doesn't make sense I know but it works for me. One bathroom makes it interesting when it's busy in the restaurant. Great for groups with their lazy Susan family type tables.
author: Johnny U.

description:
Can I give 3.5 stars? Think they truly merit 3.5....ok.. so Waverly is bursting with Chinese history... it was the street mentioned by Jade Snow Wong, kind of alley-like that only spans 2 blocks... there used to be quite a famous bakery in the day next to it, but it has since changed hands. When i look up at the tenement windows, or spy lights, my imagination wonders what sort of sad, sordid, wonderful, real-life history has occurred within those walls. It's a little otherworldy, like walking hallowed halls.. 

OK... CLAY POTS are what it's about here.... we got a lamb stew clay pot that was fall-off-bone tender, but whose flavor could have been a bit more intense, if I may ever be so candid. 

The winner, hands down, were the portions of the food!!!!!!!!!!! Really large plates that were generously laden with wok power. The breaded salt/pepper shrimp was a delightful dish, as was a very special order: finely shredded roasted nori (again, plentiful) alighting roasted pine nuts, seafood fried rice.. mix it all together, and one cannot stop at just one bowl. 

I recall there being a flounder dish and fresh fresh gailan leafy greens. the Jingdou spareribs were quite nice, albeit tad on the fattier side. Sauce was nice.

Great middle-of-road family place. Quite busy on a Saturday night.. which always adds to the ambiance when it comes to Chinese food!
author: Jana C.

description: We came to this place thinking we would get some great authentic Chinese food. We ended up getting bamboozled! We got lured into this place by a girl on the street and based on the menu and the AAA approval we thought it would be good. The service was poor, we were ignored by the staff who barely spoke English. They even rolled the restaurants big trash can out through the restaurant bumping it into chairs and patrons eating dinner. Including our party. The sake tasted odd and smelled like bleach. Even the fortune cookies were in poor taste. This place is definitely not a UTOPIA.
author: Jasmine K.

description: Tourist trap. So sad. They rip you off in price. My bill had extra charge for a very small bowl of plain white rice $1.65... Something that other Chinese restaurants give for free. Female with colored hair was rude and extremely impatient. They charge extra for as many things as possible. Never go back.
author: Phoebe C.

description:
Per coworker's recommendation. my friend and I came here for dinner to try their clay pot rice. This is because our usual favorite Chinatown location for this, Hing Lung, has been shut down by the Health Department (for how long or whether it's for good, that's unknown still).

We both agreed the clay pot rice items we ordered were good in that it's not oily compared to Hing Lung. It is more expensive though by a few dollars each depending on the item of choice. Even compared to Taishan Restaurant on Clement Street (another one of our favorite places for clay pot rice), everything is at least $1 more.

Nevertheless, chances are we'll likely we back at times to satisfy this craving if we want to go for it in Chinatown and Hing Lung remains closed.
author: H K.

description: Oops, this review was sitting in my 'Drafts' for 2 years now!  I never finished it because I realized there wasn't anything memorable about this place.  Just your run-of-the-mill greasy Canto eats for a good price (yes, even by Chinatown standards).
author: Tiffany H.

description: The food and the service was good. The food is at the saltier side but not that much that will throw you completely off. Love it and had a satisfying meal.
author: Yan Wei L.

description: Good, nice they stayed open so late for us...asked waitress her favorite dish; Mongolian Beef, meat was tender (not norm elsewhere) and tasty but it was pricey considering...tourist area perhaps.
author: J J.

description:
I went here because my friend recommended the Salt & Pepper Pork Chops... So, I ordered on the phone then went to p/u.  They said $10! I asked for a to-go menu and they brought me a sit down menu - so again I asked for a Togo menu (my friend is cheap so I know she WOULD NOT pay $10 for a meal, especially in Chinatown & a hole-in-the-wall) ... So, I looked up the prices (not on the menu) - I text my friend and say how much did she pay ... she said about $7.  I ask the women for a receipt and she gave me a blank piece of paper handwritten $10 and 1/4 of a stamp for Utopia.  I told her my friend said it was $7 when she came here - why am I being charged $10!?  Also, it's not on your menu ... she pointed to the S&P Spareribs, $8.95 - I said ya, but 1.) that is not what I ordered and 2.) it's still not $10 - she said w. tax and payment for the container ... Are you kidding me!!!???  Finally after waiting for 10 additional minutes after ordering 10 minutes before - I see a GRUNGY man come from the kitchen & throw the container w. my "chops" on the counter... I asked the women for a copy of my receipt and she photo copied a couple of Chinese symbols - that's my receipt.  Then I get back to work and it's just nasty - I show it to a coworker and they said you know that all old meat!  I didn't want to tell him that there were also all these hair like strands on 1/5 of the meat.  I hate this place!  I should have just gone to R&G my regular place MILLION times better and my food is only $7.50 and I get rice with it (not being told $1.50 for rice)!!  I threw 97% of it after finding all these lil strands and after a nasty over priced lunch - now I feel like throwing up!!

STAY THE HELL AWAY FROM THIS PLACE!!!!!
author: Nora L.

description: I don't usually rate Chinese-American restaurants unless there is something really special (or really awful) about them.  Utopia Cafe definitely merits a "shout out" as some people like to say.  It is the ONLY restaurant in SF Chinatown that I would (and have)safely recommend to either a native or a tourist.  The portions are delicious.  They are not heavy or overly spicy.  They have genuine Chinese food as well as  the usual Chinese American food.  We had some of each and nothing was overly greasy or overwhelming to the palate.  The soup was tasty and the vegetables fresh.  It's tucked out of the way on Waverly Place next to a questionable looking massage parlor (with a big sign).  If you don't like their food -- it's your loss.  This 1/8th Chinese blonde guy and his Chinese friends sure like it.
author: Robert H.

description: This food is very OK and the prices are good. Clay Pots usually take 20mins so order before you sit down if you are in a hurry.
author: Anonymous R.

description:
I'd give the place at least 3.5 stars.  We specifically came here to try a couple of the rice clay pots at lunch.  We didn't find out until AFTER we left the restaurant & went home & read one of their paper take-out menus that they'll give you 2 hrs free parking at Portsmouth garage!  I guess they'll validate.  Oh, well.... next time.  That alone was worth $6 in free parking.

The customer base today (weekend) was a mix of Asians & Whites and a token Black man who probably likes Chinese food!  

They offer 15 rice clay pots, mostly $8 and 3 which are $10 and the one frog leg clay pot for $11.  We tried the chicken/mushroom and sparerib blk bean sauce.  Tea and the house barley/carrot soup came w/the meal. The soup was quite tasty.

They cook their rice in the pot first (our 2 seat table was in the rear with a clear view of the stove in the kitchen) and then add the meat topping later.  A couple of stalks of bok choy was finally added on top of all this.  I thought the food was good, rice a bit bland but if you add a few tablespoons from the bowl of seasoned soy sauce which came w/the meal, it tastes pretty good.  

Hubby prefers the meat and seasoning mixed and cooked into the rice vs. topping and feels the rice clay pots are better at Taishan Restaurant on Clement St. for the same price.  If you're not too hungry, 3 persons can easily share 2 pots as they're filled with a lot of rice.  The staff was very nice but at lunch time, they were pretty busy.  $20 minimum for credit card use.
author: Ry T.

description:
I have mixed feelings about this place.  We were about to go to bow hon for their awesome clay pot rice when someone suggested that we come here instead.  Let me say that if what you love about clay pot rice is the crispy crust that forms around the interior walls, do not come here.  The flavor of the spare rib and sauce is totally fine but it's not done what I would call properly.  I'm not a fan of the crispiness but I do think it should be there for authenticity's sake.  I also miss the fact that they don't make soup with your pot remnants for you.

On the plus side, they serve hot lemon coke (yit ling lok) which is difficult to find as well as nai cha.  The walnut shrimp were decent as was the gai lan. The service is spare which is to be expected since we were one of two tables in the restaurant but it was sufficient.
author: Miki H.

description: The food was very good, a girl in China Town told us about this place, walked up the hill and there it was, pot stickers, chicken fried rice, sweet N sour pork yum yum. and the beer was ice cold
author: Brian P.

description:
Came here last night (8/17/13) with my family after walking up and down china town and being stopped by a girl promoting the place. 
The good was eh, ordered: 
the seafood fried rice! I'm assuming the seafood was blended in or something because I didn't see any!!!! Not even shrimp... Ugh ! 
Veggie Chow fun- it was missing flavor! 
Generals prawns- eh! They claimed to be spicy and they were not! 

So the food was nothing to brag about! It was eh! I probably could have gone to Panda Express and gotten better food!

Now lets talk about service! Oh boy!!! 
1st off there were only 2 girls working the place... We were sitting for about 5 mins before they even asked if we wanted water!! We were ready to order and we had to sit there forever before we decided to flag someone down! Finally we order and food slowly starts rolling in! 1st dish was duck (didn't review this because I didn't try it) well our waitress spilled the broth all over the table! Did she bring a rag to clean the mess?!? Nope!!! Didn't even bother! 
Not once did we get our water refilled! I had to flag someone down and ask for some! After the food arrived no one stopped at our table to check on us.. The only ones who stopped at our table were mosquitoes! Oh my god!!! About a million of them! How dirty is this place that during the entire meal we had to keep shooing them  away! The waitress even killed one with her hand... Eew!! 
So we are not yet done eating it was pretty obvious since my mom and brother were still eating and the waitress comes and says "you done?!?" Uh NO!!!! Do you not see them eating! Don't try to rush us!! WTF! 
So finally we finish eating and my dad went up to the counter to pay.. Total was $48 and change and my dad gave her a $50.. He left the change on the tray! And my mom was leaving a tip on the table... It's what they always do! Wellll I hear the lady saying something to my dad.. And my dad didn't understand or just looked extremely confused so I get up and ask what the problem was and waitress goes "tips tips" I go "EXcuse me?!?!?!" She points at the tray and writes it down "TIPS" for my services tips!! I go "oh honey! You're not supposed to ask! Now just because you asked you don't get one!!!" 
Uh helllllller!!!!! What kind of service is that?!?!? You didn't even refill my water! You spilled food on the table and didn't bother to clean it! You have a nasty restaurant infested with mosquitoes! And you dare ask for a tip for your services?!?!? Excuse me but NO!!!! I have never EVER been to such a place! And have never been demanded a tip!! Like I said we obviously were going to leave one! Very extremely bothered!!! 
So that was our experience at this nasty, dirty, rude place! --____--
author: Liz C.

description: Horrible service! This restaurant has a sign saying that they are open till 10pm on Sundays.   I went there at 9:30 at night and they refused to serve me.  Meanwhile the lights were still on outside and the door was open.
author: WINNIE B.

description: So I guess I will have to come back for the clay pot rice...since we didn't get it that day. The meal was pretty average along with the prices.
author: Eve C.

description: Worst service i have ever had.  Food was ok but service was horrible.  My family and i decided to give this place a try, big mistake.  Orders came out wrong. upon receiving the check plates were literally snached out of my hands. We asked for more hot tea and 2 minutes after receiving it it was swiftly taken away with a finger pointing at the door.  left feeling disrespected and sick.  This place is not for tourists.
author: Blake S.

description:
The food is just OK.
But it takes long time to wait for the food and they don't accept car for the deal under $25.
author: Kan W.

description: Woman handing out fliers for this place told us if we spend $20 we'd get a plate of wings for $1. Another woman with her said yeah and she'll get commission for bringing you. So we thought why not. Good deal and we're helping this woman out. We ordered sesame chicken and calamari which were actually pretty decent. We get the check which came to $21 and figured great we'll get our $1 win gs now. The owner or manager laughed when we asked for our wings and said oh that girl tells people that all the time. You need to spend $30 and walked away. Food was decent but plz don't pull a fast one on people.
author: Sigmund W.

description: Tourist trap! I've eaten at many chinese places and this is one if the worst. Kind of weird since they will show you their SF Chronicle prizes... I would spend money on a different restaurant.
author: David D.

description: OMG, best duck ever! I asked the waitress what type of style this was and she said just Chinese roasted duck.  The chef only spoke Chinese so I gave him the thumbs up and $10 tip.  The only reason for going to San Francisco would be for the roasted duck and Pier 39 on the weekend.
author: Orlando C.

description:
Utopia is my "go to" for clay pot when I want a relaxed lunch with my friends.  (I like to bring my own apple juice and no one minds.)    My favorite dish is the Oyster/Pork clay pot and the Salty fish/Pork clay pot.  These dishes are about $7 each and very generous in portions!

Utopia always serves a nice soup with the meal - which is a plus - because it's healthy home made Chinese soup.

I've friends who enjoy american-chinese food and they always order the orange-chicken or the kung pao chicken which I find boring - but at the Utopia, it's actually pretty good.  I taste it once in a while to be friendly, but it's not what I am looking for when I go to China Town.

How do you know the food is good?  Because there are always a flock of  Chinese in there eating and having a good time.    If you enjoy people-watching the Utopia is good.

The servers are responsive, helpful and friendly.  Being a guai lo, I like to try out my broken Chinese on them and they are good natured at my feeble attempts; always giving me a smile and sometimes comprehending.  I had a hard time asking for a glass for my apple juice, and they taught me the correct phrase:  "sui bui" - meaning "water glass".
author: Steve S.

description:
It was on my bookmarked list to try ( but I didn't even try the claypots!). 

*dou mei
*seafood claypot
*salt fish with rice
author: Jboogie L.

description: Hot Pot Rice was not bad. It needed a bit more flavor and the meat had bones in it (which sucked)! Usually they give you more flavorful pieces that are deboned. Also it was $11 after tax and tip. For Chinatown standards, that's expensive!
author: Wilson T.

description:
Came back to try it when I was in the neighborhood and wanted...well, fast and cheap.

This time, the server was almost entirely MIA (waved her down six times before she noticed...and then took the longest time to get iced water for another table before coming).

Food was decent. But as we came in the evening, there were no real specials. We ordered a 3 dishes combo...and paid extra for rice (seriously? Who eats side dishes without rice?!? I hate when places charge this... $1 per person...).  Food was generally OK, but nothing really with a "wow" factor. The Chinese-style beef texturally and taste was fine...just weird how it sat on a bed of raw onions. o.O real weird...

I'm still not seeing a wow-factor that makes me want to return as a frequent customer...
author: Lily W.

description:
Noted as one of SF Examiner's Top 10 Chinese restaurants in 2003 and featured in San Francisco: Great Escapes magazine for May 2003, they sure have gone downhill since then.

I was running some errands today through the rainy mess and had to hit up Chinatown.  I figure I would grab some lunch, and passed by this cafe in the alleyway of Waverly Place.  Nestled between the suki suki Double Dragon Massage parlor and the Wonderful Foods Co., it's quite easy to miss.

I noted that most, if not all the diners were Asian, Chinese-speaking Asian.  Usually a good sign, right?  I ended up with the Chow Fun, dry style.  I requested it vegetarian.  This cost me $6.25.  I figure with that price, they would take out meat and throw in some veggies....any veggies would be good at this point!  I would be so happy if I found broccoli, snow peas, carrots, mushrooms, string beans, or even cabbage!

I got back to the office and this is what I found...a box of brown noodles with no taste, bean sprouts, onions, and green onions.  Shute, all those 'veggies' would have been in the regular order anyway!  Now I'm stuck eating a box of greasy noodles with no substance whatsoever!  Argh!  I hate this.  Thank gawd for hot sauce.  Okay, so it does look like I have an overabundance of bean sprouts in there, but hey, bean sprouts are damn cheap!  (I'm beginning to pick them out now 'cuz there's so much!)

If I'm ever dragged back there, maybe I'll have to get there salt and pepper rock cod that was featured in the magazine.  But yeah, no to go orders for me anymore from here! Blah!

Sidenote: They offer two hours free parking at Portsmouth Garage with a minimum $20-$25 purchase (depending on what sign you read).  They also have the 'secret' Chinese menus posted inside and out...y'know, the specials that are a steal but only if you can read Chinese can you order from it.  I can't read Chinese, oh well.  I feel stiffed!
author: Teri C.

description:
I'm guessing that the person who named this restaurant had a wicked sense of humor, unless being insolent to one another is normal behavior in the Chinese Utopian society.  

The waitresses here were contemptuously rude and, at times, downright hostile.  That's rather unfortunate, because the food here was pretty good.  The sweet and sour chicken dish and the bean sprout leaves with garlic dish were particularly tasty.  

And the price was easy on the pocket book.  Our bill averaged out to about $12 per person.  By the way, if you want to know what a hardcore stink eye looks like, just ask the waitress to split the bill with multiple credit cards.
author: Subrosa I.

description: The tea was nothing special. They gave us some kind of free mystery meat soup, which was weird. The ingredients in the wor wonton soup were nice and hefty. The e-noodles with seafood were ok. But their signature dish, the clay rice pot, was incredibly salty and a huge disappointment. Their bathroom was also a storage closet near a bunch of dirty fish tanks. So, should you try now? Nah...
author: Try Now U.

description: This place was great! The food was fresh and priced good! The owner and workers were all so friendly we will definatly be going back!
author: Arissa R.

description:
Horrible service 
 Disappointing meal-- ordered stir fried beef with scallion (50% of ginger and 50% beef)...i was not here for the ginger!!!!!
Prawns with walnut small portion and no fresh at all!
The waitress is SUPER RUDE and asked for more trip that they deserved!
Worst experience EVER!  Never returning again!!!
author: Hola H.

description:
Pros:

Tasty dishes; Fried rice with pine nuts, egg white with shrimp and chicken, kau yuk vegetables

Cons:
Simple cafe setting

*****
Enjoyed dishes that were original to me. Will come again.
author: Kona B.

description:
3 1/2 stars.

The Beef Stew Noodle was da BOMB! The piece of beef were tender and excellent. The broth was just right

Wife had the dumpling Noodle Soup - it was OK. The dumpling was pork as opposed to shrimp.

They offer 2 hours Free Parking at Portsmouth Garage which is a MAJOR PLUS.

Service was OK, but on the slow side.
author: Peter L.

description: Cheap solid Chinese food with an excellent list of clay pots.  Can't wait to go back again.  Service was typically what I would have expected from a hole in the wall Chinese restaurant.
author: C L.

description: Love this place! Cheap, quality food. Great service too.
author: Katie J.

description:
Read about this place in San Francisco magazine and decided to give it a try.  Never even knew this place existed.  The Chinese name to this place is quite unique - ginseng satisfy porridge - but basically it's food that'll you'll be satisfy with.

Now, they are also famous for their clay pot rice and is there any Chinese who doesn't LOVE this dish?  It's not a fancy dish but it's not easy to make it right.  Wherever they served them, we have tried and this place is the BEST yet.  You must know a little about this dish to understand or try to catch the episode when Anthony Bourdain was in Hong Kong.  It's rice with whatever toppings slow cooked in a clay pot -the result is a layer of crispy goodness and flavorful rice from whatever topping you choose (black bean sparerib, chicken with mushroom and chinese sausage, combo of preserved meat and chinese sausage, salty fish pork patty, beef patty...the possibilities can be endless and establishments are getting very creative.).

We ordered the finely minced preserved cabbage and beef clay pot rice - it was made perfectly.  The beef was flavorful and every grain of the rice was perfect.  The crunchy goodness was just divine and of course, the sweetened soy sauce makes the meal complete.  The plus was the rice also included some tender greens.  $6.95!

We decided to try the pork giblet porridge ($4.50) and the bok choy chicken pan fried noodles ($6.25).  The porridge was ok - the thickness was just right, the ingredients were a bit overcooked and it was lacking a bit of taste.  The pan fried noodles was tasty and surprisingly not oily as expected - the chicken was a bit 'choppy' and the bok choy was just ok.

So all this was less than $20 and we had left over to bring home, not to mention the free bowl of the house soup and dessert (taro with tapioca).  

From looking around, I see their stir fried dishes are most popular and they all looked very good.  We will definitely return for the clay pot rice - likely will get two and try one of their 15 flavors although the frog one is always tempting. 

Big plus:  they validate up to 2 hours of parking at Portsmouth Square!  We did see a sign on the door re: change of ownership.  Like many HK styled restaurants, they also have 'Happy Hour' from 3-5pm? where many snacks, noodles and rice dishes are at discounted price.
author: Gloria H.

description: The worst service I have ever had. Waitress always argued. It's expensive and worthless. I would never go back to this restaurant. Never!!!!! Their food is the worst too.:((
author: Eunice C.

description:
The lovely Vicky L. and I came here yesterday for lunch. I love that she works in Chinatown and has recommendations for spots since I have no idea about cantonese food. 
That being said, Utopia Cafe is known for their clay pots, or so I figure from reading other reviews and the fact that their menu has like 30 of them on it. I was very undecided about what to order so I read the whole menu and alas, they have my favorite Chinese lunch item! 
SCRAMBLED EGGS WITH TOMATO
It's exactly what it sounds like, a huge plate of eggs with stewed tomatoes. This is a very "Chinese" thing to eat, considering this is what I ate and what everyone else ate for lunch when I was living in northern China. I would definitely go back to Utopia Cafe just for this dish, since I haven't seen it anywhere else. However, I would have to try more items on their menu to justify giving more stars.
author: Sara P.

description: Coming from Europe where I had terrible Chinese food for weeks, this place was a godsend. I liked the claypot rice and the wanton soup. We'll be back to get noodles and other delicious things when I'm feeling like I need a taste of home.
author: Adrianna T.

description:
Utopia?  Umm, I think we must be consulting very different dictionaries...

Now I know this place is in Chinatown and so I can't hold it to the standards of a five star restaurant...but:

- dried rice left in "clean" bowls
- only 2 menus thrown at our table when we had 3 people
- I had the fresh fish porridge which was so bland I had to use pepper and hot sauce to give it flavor
- poor service; workers seemed frustrated and were yelling that they were too busy

yeah...'nuff said.
author: Alvina W.

description:
So here's one of those hole-in-the-wall chinese places that I absolutely love!!!

Located in an alley of Chinatown, you get this weird feeling like you've discovered a whole new part of the neighborhood. Waverly Place has been recently redone so it looks a little cleaner, but still it's a cool little alleyway as you walk north with the view of the old ornate buildings.

Everytime we take friends there, they're like 'What? You're taking us here?' - and i'm just like 'HELL YEAH!!!' - it's not the prettiest of places.

The food however makes up for appearance of the restaurant. The dish that everyone in the world must try is the Sweet and Sour Chicken. It's to die for. First time I tried it... pure ecstasy! I was like oh. my. god. this sh!t is good.

I gave it four stars because sometimes we have to wait forever, and the service is not always what it should be,,, the prices are awesome.... we never spend more than 20 bucks for two people...

Give it a try!
author: Richard T.

description: I love this resturant! It has very good food and it has very good serivce! People should try the rice clay pot and clay pot plate! The chef cooks them at the tranditional way!
author: Cherry Q.

description: Went here for a quick meal after getting a haircut in Chinatown. A pretty good/faithful Cantonese cafe-type restaurant.
author: Thomas C.

description: I was hungry because I didn't have dinner. I immediately thought about clay pot rice at Utopia. It's always consistently good and satisfying. I usually go with the chicken mushroom and Chinese sausage. The also have great veggie dishes too. I recommend this place.
author: Jeff L.

description: Great authentic Chinese food. They had the best pot stickers ever. We also had beef with broccoli, so fresh and tasty.
author: Shellie R.

description:
The clay pot rice was done right with the right amount of rice crusted in the pot.  

Surprisingly clean for being in the alley.  

Exceeded expectations based on my one visit.
author: Chanson H.

description:
Great good, nice people.

I had the preserved sausage and duck rice clay pot, chicken wings, vege with garlic, and the west lake beef soup.

Love the rice clay pot and chicken wings, very tasty

The soup was pretty good, a warm addition to the cold day

vege with garlic was prepared like how my mom used to cook it, reminds me a lot of home

Overall, great service and food, definitely recommend people coming here
author: Eric L.

description: This place was such a disappointment. First my chicken in lemon sauce was nothing more than a bunch of over fried chicken nuggets with some bottled sauce dripped on top of it. The waitress dropped off the food and never saw her again for 30 minutes until she brought the check by.
author: Matthew F.

description: My family are regulars of this place when they're in Chinatown.  Good clay pot rice dishes.  Their steamed fish and crab was pretty good.  They do validate parking which is a plus.
author: Wendy L.

description:
Delicious unpretentious Cantonese food, graciously served by attentive staff. Really was surprised by the quality and flavor of what was served.

Looks like somewhere you could grab a quick lunch, but my husband brought me here for dinner. I was surprised. It was a delightful treat.

Might be better suited for people seeking authentic cuisine, rather than egg foo young and fried rice.
author: Mitzi N.

description: I think this restaurant has a very special Chinatown feeling located in a Historic Temple Alley.  The food is very authentic and the food is always consistently good.  So many regulars there that you are always bound to run into friends there.  The Clay Pot dishes are their specialty, the way food was cooked in the old Chinese Village in China.
author: Ron L.

description:
Living in San Francisco its hard to have a regular Chinese restaurant as there as many to choose from.

I had not eaten at Utopia for awhile and thought it was high time I went back as I was craving a Claypot dish.

Oh it was delicious...its very tasty and fantastic value for money.  If you want to try a claypot dish then I really recommend Utopia.

I love the fact its nestled into a side street and for me its more of an authentic Chinese restaurant than many of the places which are more for tourists. Yum! I will be back.
author: Shane W.

description:
I skipped the shady Double Dragon Massage with the single light bulb next store and ventured into Utopia (quite literally and figuratively).

Travelers and locals alike should pay a visit to Utopia Cafe located on prominent Waverly Alley aka the street with the "decorated" balconies in antiquated Chinese fashion. 

I'm surprised that I've never visited Utopia Cafe until today. I was pleasantly surprised that the service was great (especially considering the other "services" I've received in and around Chinatown) and the waitress was very friendly and helpful. I asked for recommendations for the noodle dishes and she said the duck one was rather good. I went with her recommendation and loved it. It was a sizable portion for $8.95 and I was stuffed leaving the restaurant. The noodles were delicious and I received an ample amount of duck meat. 

Ambiance: It's not a fancy place, but rather PLEASANT. I was able to have a great conversation with my friend it was not loud at all. Great, clean place to eat, chat, and exchange thoughts.

Transportation/Location: Located between Grant and Stockton/offshoot Washington Street. Convenient location near multiple MUNI lines including 30, 45, 8x, 1, and the cable car.

Tip: Come here for happy hour from 2:30pm to 5pm. Things are cheaper. For example, most of the cold drinks are $1 less and some of the small plates/entrees are $1-$2 less too for the same size.
author: Tina C.

description: Awesome food and great portions for a very reasonable price!  I'd come again, but they lose a star for slow/inattentive service. I had to flag the waitress down a few times to get a water refill or to get the check at the end.
author: Michael S.

description: Epicurious recommended this restaurant, although I'm not sure why. Service was great, food was average or below. It was definitely not the Chinese feast we were hoping for.  Hong Kong style chow mein was mostly chewy squid and bok choy. Clay pot with black bean ribs lacked flavor and ribs were boney. All in all mediocre at best.
author: Carrie L.

description: Like many other yelpers, we were sucked in by the lady handing out flyers. The place wasn't too packed and we were seated right away. Soon after a big group comes in and they are immediately served their drinks. About ten minutes passed and the waitress finally comes by to take our food and drink orders. The food was decent, but in all honesty the service was horrible. The waitress was rude, pushy, and never checked back on us to see if we needed anything else. The cherry on top of it all...when paying for the tab we took the advice of another yelper and paid with cash and the waitress advised us that our tab did not include a tip. She ended up taking what we had given her even though we intended on receiving our change back.  My advice for future customers: please be sure to always have change when coming to this place because they will NOT return your change if it does not include a sufficient tip.
author: Bee C.

description: All these years i've been around chinatown, i've never been here til this week. Came here after basketball and we were HUNGRY! we ordered alot of food, i dont recall how many dishes we ordered but we ordered family style. Bill came out to be decent, not too much for the amount of food we ate. Service was great! friendly, fast, and very efficient. Will be coming back in the near future! :)
author: Q W.

description: This place is just ok, nothing spectacular or special. In our case we had been walking for hours in Chinatown, with all the hustle going on....horns going off like crazy, tourists like myself walking around shopping.  This happen to be the first place we see and by this time we were on the verge of collapsing from not having eaten. Even so it was just ok. The water tasted funny, it was pretty warm that day and they gave me like 2 ice cubes with my water. Come on! If you happen to be walking by and need food ASAP and feel like you can't take another step, go on in....it won't kill you but it won't change your life for good either. Just something to quiet your tummy until you can get some REAL food in you. Oh and careful when paying for your bill in cash, we paid the lady and she took it upon herself to assume the change was her tip. She never came back with our change so I had to go up there and get my change.
author: Jo S.

description: This place was my very first spot in frisco, and first ever yelp choice thanks to my gf,  this is where my yelp adventure began . I've ordered the general tsao chicken since i im into spicy food. The chicken was okay it was saucy had chopped vegies, it was a tad sweet and lil spicy but overall not bad. The staff was helpful and friendly this place is original and you will have the feel of chinatown.
author: Jon B.

description:
I don't get the negative reviews?  I went there for dinner with my GF, and found the place to be clean, quiet, well lit, and organized -- and, it wasn't over-crowded with tables.  The servers were attentive and polite, constantly bringing things, taking plates away, and I just can't see anything missing.

The atmosphere was nice, too - everyone seemed to know everyone else, like it was a neighborhood hangout full of regulars who knew each other.  Seemed like there was a party downstairs.

The food:  I had the General's Rock Cod, and it was delicious -- not too heavy, and not oily.  In fact, all of the dishes were cooked very well, and they were very tasty - we also had the salt and pepper chicken wings (they were excellent), one of the clay-pot rice dishes (I think it was the Chinese Sausage and Preserved Duck Rice), which was delicious, especially if, like me, you enjoy the crispy rice that gets stuck to the sides of the clay pot.  We also had a vegetable that was tasty.

I do think this is authentic Chinese, so factor that into your decision.
author: david p.

description: The food was amazing and the service was great. They bill themselves a Hong Kong Clay Pot restaurant, so we ordered the Preserved Duck and Chinese Sausage Clay Pot and it was delicious, filling and not overly salted, the flavors were very balanced. Can also recommend the salt and pepper calamari, mongolian beef, egg flower soup and spicy wonton soup. We rolled ourselves home after this meal completely satisfied.
author: Charles S.

description:
Went to try and buy the salt and pepper chicken wings and mentions saw  the special on yelp to get it for $1.95.  But they want the printout of the coupon.   

Yelp said  "This is our special tasting item, and is available for dinner for yelp readers. Please mention that you read this offer from http://yelp.com.
'

Thats what I did, so I'm going back to show them this also happen last time they had this ad.

The lady at the counter seems like the owner with glasses and short hair and don't understand english that will. Hopefully, someone can explain to her in Cantonese about the yelp special, because I can't speak that good.
author: John F.

description: I'd give you a 0 if I could but the only saving grace was the one employee who I think was either actually a family member or just eating there on her off night and was more attentive to us than our actual waitress. Service beyond terrible, tried a number of dishes and they were bland. I was really bummed I had read such great stuff about the food. Maybe it was an off night....it was a full moon and all?
author: Lauren V.

description: After re-reading my review and communicating with the owner, I am revising the rating. I was, perhaps, a bit snarky and unfair. I think it speaks volumes about an establishment when the owner shows genuine concern about the product he is putting out there and the clients he is serving. Every place is entitlled to ONE (and only one!) off night. Hopefully, my bad experience was a fluke and my next one will be different. Fingers crossed.
author: carol c.

description:
I always come here for their happy hour specials. 2:00 - 5:00

My friends and I would always get their "Ja Jang Lai Mien". Oh btw, the menu is in chinese for the happy hour so bring someone who knows how to read chinese. Sorry non-readers LOL

But seriously, the ja jang lai mien is to DIE FOR! Omg the noodles are so soft and slippery.. and the soup. Don't even get me started on the soup! It's tangy, sweet, spicy.. You just have to try it.

The next dish we'd get would be the "jiew yeem dao fu pok" (salt&peppa tofu cubes). The outside of the tofu is just perfectly crisp and the tofu inside is soft and can just melt in your mouth. Be sure they give you the soy sauce for it, and add hot sauce to it. Don't use the soy sauce on the table, it's different.

These two are the best I've ever had at this restaurant and at any other restaurant. 

The one thing I don't like is their "hong dao bing" or "luk dao bing" (red bean ice or green bean ice). They put tangerine peels in it. I know some people like it with it, but just my personal taste, I don't like it.
author: Jenny Y.

description: This is one of my favorite places in Chinatown, having lived and worked in the area for a long time, i have tasted many different Chinatown places. Utopia has excellent Clay Pot Combinations and Rice Porridges. The food is always fresh, always try to Clay Pot and sticky clay pot is awesome!!!!
author: Carlos S.

description: A wonderful establishment! Sometimes, at night, I dream of the  good as it's calling out to me! So good. Can you say "mouthgasm"?
author: G G.

description:
I came back on a weekend night and the food is still yummy. I tried the chicken and mushroom clay pot, chinese brocolli, walnut shrimp, and beef chow fun. I was disappointed that the rice was not as crunchy at the bottom, but the rice was still delicious, nonetheless. 

You can get better chow fun at other chinese restaurants, but the restaurant is clean, service is good, and MSG isn't used as a main seasoning, like at other chinese restaurants.
author: Robin K.

description:
Um, yes, I did have Chinese food two days in a row.  What?

Utopia=awesome.  Funky, flavorful wonton soup, cheap veggie dinner options (fried rice, tofu with bok choy and mushrooms, veggie mu shu, spring rolls, and soup for $9.99/each?  Yes please), and amazingly fresh and flavorful hot n' sour fish.  Fish from the tank in the back, it's that fresh.  Utopia is a find, and the young waitress with adorable hair is the best ever; super nice and helpful.  Four and not five stars for the occasionally not-terrifically-clean quarters, but what're you gonna do?
author: Alanna C.

description: My favorite restaurant in the United States. Seriously. I love the duck soup and the steamed greens.  The neighborhood is wonderful and it's right around the corner from City Lights and Vesuvio, making it the perfect spot for a date.  The best.
author: Nicole D.

description: I stepped into the small restaurant just off Grant for lunch.  Food was very good and inexpensive.  I had the Quail Clay Pot.  The quail & veggies were not over cooked and the rice was not at all oily.  The menu is quite extensive, my only wish was that they had a better selection of teas.  It may have been the day I was there, but they were out of a couple of types of tea (and there are only three or four on the menu).  It's definitely worth a shot if you're in Chinatown.
author: James H.

description:
Hands down to this place, not only because their food was great, but service wasn't bad and the restaurant is pretty clean compared to all the others that I've been too in chinatown.

I'm so glad that my parents introduced me to this place because I've been craving for those clay pots with rice.  YUMMY!!!

The only reason why I'm giving Utopia 3 stars is because we were here the other night  for dinner.  There was another family of four right next to us and yes they were tourist, which is fine with me.  When we were getting ready to pay our tab, that tourist family questioned their bill and why they were getting taxed twice on their tab.  When the father/husband questioned the waitress, she basically told him that it was tip and tax.  Excuse me, but I thought most restaurants automatically tip if you have a party of 6 or more.  I thought that was not cool at all because when we looked at our tab, we never got the tip added to our tab.
author: Shana W.

description: we were here for lunch & the place was busy.  They directed us to sit downstairs (smelled of smoke & strange odors).  You know what they say, out of sight, out of mind.  We had to go upstairs to ask for tea.  We had absolutely NO SERVICE.  The only thing they did do was bring our food.  We  even had to go upstairs for our check.  When we paid our bill, the waitress had the nerve to ask us where her tip was.  We told her she wasn't getting one, exactly the same as the service we never got.
author: Kendall R.

description:
Wish I knew about the $1.95 wings before I went!!

Came here for dinner by recommendation of family as a sticky hole in the wall chinese restaurant.  (That's where you find the best food!)  Anyways, as we drove up the dark alley, saw the bright lights of the Double Dragon Massage place...then Utopia...it proved to be promising.  You can hear old opera music and mah-jong as you exit the car.  

The ladies that work there speak limited English.  We got the $28 set menu, added the sizzling frog claypot and salt fish fried rice.  The set menu came with soup (seafood and tofu), greens, steamed mushroom chicken, sweet and sour pork, and whole fried sole.  Definitely a lot of food for 4 people!  The food was fulfilling.  The claypot was excellent!  I would eat here again...just have to remember to bring more people!
author: Eegnam A.

description: I love it. Even though it is a small restaurant. The food is tasty because I am eating it right now. I know it has Wi-Fi network because I am using it to type this right now! The soup is not bad. I will try to go here as many times as possible.
author: William Z.

description:
The food might have been good but they really need to learn something about customer service.  I just finished dinner with a friend there tonight and tried to get my parking ticket validated.  The woman at the cash register told me that they could not validate me because there was a $30 minimum before they could validate.  What was my bill?  $29.40.  So for a lousy SIXTY CENTS, they were willing to forego any future visits by me and my friend.  

I'm sorry, but you'd think for SIXTY lousy cents, they'd be willing to validate a parking ticket.

Very Disappointed.

Strike this place off my list for a return visit
author: Vincent K.

description:
This is the ultimate chinese "hole in the wall."  Obscure location on an side alley street - Waverly Place, just block up from Grant St, it is worth the trip to find.  The clay pots are great, and I also love their Beef Stew Won Ton.  Truly, a place for locals and tourists, i can qualify as both, having been born in the city but since moved elsewhere.  Free parking too at Portsmouth Square with a minimum purchase. 

A MUST TRY. It is not fine dining, by any means, but it is the king of its niche.
author: Z W.

description: Came here yesterday for a late lunch early dinner before the parade.  I love the clean no frills atmosphere and friendly service.  It is a small place with a small number of employees, so expect to wait for service at times.  The pot stickers were a bit doughty, not crispy golden like I am use to; the filling was good but spectacular.  The egg rolls were crispy with a perfect vegetable filling and well balanced sweet & sour sauce.  The salt & pepper chicken wings are crispy with a light sprinkling of five spices.  The beef Hong Kong noodles are good with tender beef, bean sprouts, and chow fun in a light sauce.  All & all okay, I have experienced better.
author: Brian S.

description: I was looking forward to eating the claypot rice here but was a bit disappointed.  The chicken mushroom claypot rice I had was bland since sauce is given on the side and not cooked with the ingredients.  The sauce is also a very thin consistency and did not have enough flavor.
author: dolly s.

description: This is an excellent little place in Chinatown for a meal. The Salt & Pepper Chicken Wings from the appetizer menu are delicious. Be sure to mention Yelp.com to get them for $1.95 - it is a smaller serving compared to the item from the appetizer menu (5 instead of 10). They are excellent and at a much better deal.
author: Joe Y.

description: I like their HK style clay rice pots! They offer a large variety of clay pots. My favorite is frog rice clay pot. It takes a long time to make (30 mins), better to call order ahead! You can also order on line.
author: Emmy P.

description: The salt and pepper wings are a must have. Tried the pork ribs with black bean sauce clay pot as well - delicious! We finished everything.  Great service as well!   Can't beat for a late night eat in SF's Chinatown. I've tried a few places in SF for Chinese, and this is my new fave!
author: C T.

description:
Service is pitiful and the wait for the food to come is too long.

The clay pots for which they are supposed to be known for were unremarkable, for me at least.

They have the best pan fried noodles (aka chow mein) that I have tasted so far. Not too dry as most thin noodles are and not too greasy. 

The portions are small, IMHO, and the prices are average (but a little high comparatively speaking).
author: John C.

description: I love this place, it's simple Chinese food done right. You cannot go wrong with their clay pots and chicken wings :)
author: June Y.

description: While you can dismiss it as being like any other Chinese food joint in Chinatown, their claypots are a favorite--and they happen to serve up a decent tofu and gluten claypot of gigantic proportions.  (Do be weary of the broth not being veg friendly).  Packed with locals, the dining area is cramped, and not any cleaner than nearby establishments.  But the waitstaff were noticeably friendly, exchanging pleasantries, which I'm not used to experiencing when patronizing a more traditional restaurant that caters toward the Chinese-speaking population.  Just a short jaunt away, it's a change of pace from the FiDi's measly lunchtime offerings.
author: Marsha Z.

description: Get the seasame sweet and sour chicken with cilantro. Out of this world good!
author: Aeyrie R.

description:
My quick rule of thumb for picking out a decent cheap Chinese place in SF:
The yellow ratio - if Chinese customers to non-Chinese customers is at least 3:2 then you're good to go on the grounds of authenticity, menu selection, and the ability to customize your order.  If there aren't enough tables of people in the restaurant to apply the ratio, well that's not a good sign in the first place.

So how was this rule successfully applied to Utopia cafe?  Well first, I was a little thrown by the name Utopia restaurant.  I mean Utopia?  That's way more whitified than something like New Sun Hong Kong Restaurant, which is essentially as redundant as saying "Chai Tea" and whitified normally means too salty and greasy in my book to be any good.  But the cheery yellow awning and random icicle lights in the middle of Waverly alley at least convinced my friend and I to walk up to the window and peer in.

And that's when we applied the rule - more Chinese people than white.  Sweet.  Let's go in.

How did we fair?  Well, it was decent food!  I was still nursing (at 9pm) a hangover from the previous night, so I was craving salt and pepper fried chicken wings.  They came out quite perfect.  Tasty, piping hot, and juicy.  Plus, they had clay pot rice, which while it looked like a large hamburger patty slapped on top of a pot of rice, was savory and crispy on the edges.

Despite the decent food, it's a 3 star place because I hate it when there are fruit flies buzzing around a restaurant.  I've seen fruit flies in all kinds of restaurants, regardless of cleanliness expectations, but it just gives me the eebie jeebies.  And I counted 2 fruit flies constantly circling our table last night.
author: Audrey T.

description:
1 star...1 star.. if i could give zero, you would've received a zero! NEVER COMING BACK HERE EVER AGAIN!!!!!! 

OK.. the food is good, its not bad. The Clay Pot Rice is to die for, but the Salt and Pepper Chicken wings were HORRIBLE! They came out Half cooked half raw! WTF!?! how are you going to serve us raw chicken? When it came to the table, it looked ok, but after a minute sitting on the table... blood started dripping out.. it leaked out of the chicken... wtf.. so we complained... we told them to take it away, and that we didn't want it. When we asked for the bill, the chicken wings were still on there, and we asked the waitress why is was still on the bill. She said we ordered it, and that she could only replace it with a different dish.. and we said, hell no.. we want a refund, but she wouldn't give it to us. HOW ARE YOU GOING TO SERVE RAW CHICKEN to your customers and not refund us the money!? I WILL NEVER EVER COME BACK HERE EVER A AGAIN!!! Learn some business ethics! DOUCHE BAGS!
author: Brian P.

description: I love this place. It's authentic amazingly delicious Chinese food. There is a genuine family feel since many family members are on hand to make suggestions to, chat and laugh with as well as serve patrons. Don't miss this jewel of a place. Try the mixed egg and seafood. You'll be pleasantly surprised.
author: R C.

description: A hidden gem in Chinatown! Like many others have said, you know you are in a good place when you see all of the locals eating there. Get the clay pots - they are fantastic!
author: Trey C.

description: Really pleasant service, but the food was bland. I was hungry, and this place was in front of me, I went in, the menu seemed to keep saying clay pot, clay pot, but no I wanted a wonton soup, and some other stuff. It was Ok, but unmemorable, and at least it did not taste like clay, but maybe close. Maybe I got the wrong stuff. A better tomorrow. Bye.
author: Miguel L.

description: I came here on my last day in SF, right before my flight. Not exactly hole in the wall joint, but somewhere in that category. we were seated promptly, water and tea was bought to us. We ordered a few entree intems and all were excellent. The only disappointment was the clay pot! After reading about this place and their infamous clay pot, i had to order one. The rice on the bottom was soggy, and topping were spare. Would I give it a try, again? Yes!
author: Joy M.

description:
Great value and the clay pot really is the attraction.  The smoked duck and preserved pork type was good, but not great.  However, at $7 it is hardly anything to be disappointed about.  They do the basic chinese dishes and seemed to have some dishes tailored for the american tastes.  For the price, I would be very hard pressed to go elsewhere and get food just as good.

Like somebody else, I had the buzzing fruit fly issue.  Service is definitely their sore spot, but you just need to be aware of the shortcoming.

Beers and a 3 course meal for two grown adults was under 30 bucks.
author: Simon Y.

description: Great authentic Chinese food.  Obviously a local favorite as we were the only 2 tourists in the full restaurant.  Tasty and affordable. Highly recommend!
author: Sierra C.

description: This truly is the best value restaurant in the City.  Could have fed 3 people easily and only $22.  All food prepared to order.
author: Laurence H.

description:
I've been to almost every restaurant in Chinatown and this is a place has made it onto our list of regular take-out places.  The service isn't anything special, but what do you expect from a place in Chinatown.  My favorite things to order are:

Roast pork and oyster clay pot
Chicken fried rice
Beef chow fun

Don't order the water melon drink ... you'll be disappointed!
author: Rod C.

description:
My wife being asian and myself have been to chinatown many times, always looking for a good place to eat.  Last night we found it in Utopia.  We did one of the set dinners,  we had a large party, so did the $88 special for the group.  Wow, the food was great!  The service outstanding.....The price....felt like I was back in Taiwan, 
After looking at the other reviews here, will have to go back for the clay pot, since we did not have,  but we did have the ribs....crab, chicken,  all finger licking good....
author: Bob H.

description: We were so excited to find this place.  The absolute best salt and pepper chicken wings, calamari and curry shrimp we have ever tasted.  The sake was also very tasty and the price for the whole meal was so reasonable!   We will be back!
author: Eleanore M.

description:
I was here recently while working on a show, and I have to say I really like the place.
 The noodle soup with fish balls and meat balls were great. I liked the tea, although it could have been a bit hotter. The only thing that was lacking were the egg rolls. The filling was a bit on the bland side, however, the pork was good, and a little hot sauce woke it up.
 I will definitely be back.
author: Andy H.

description:
The food was pretty good-- really tasty and fresh egg rolls (not soggy at all), good chicken fried rice, but sort of bland beef chow fun.  
However, as has been noted: there is a fruit fly issue.  When my boyfriend noted the bug zapper behind the counter we were a little concerned, when he found a fruit fly in the chow fun, that was pretty much the end of the meal.  I'd like to think that maybe it died sometime after the food hit our table, but still, it's something that they really should take care of.
author: Alison M.

description:
Best Kept Secret!

First understand that Chinese food has many categories... and fortunately for us we have Utopia Cafe to show us the other end of all that is good and not expensive.  

Utopia Cafe is a place where the food is more Chinese Cafe style than that of a full dinner restaurant like R&G.  As a Hong Kong average kinda guy, this place totally hits the spot when I want to get some normal eats at 6-8 dollars a person out the door.  From porridge to noodles this place has all the good stuff, and it taste fresh and home made without the MSG.  I recommend their salt and pepper chicken wings... don't ask just order!  Their porridge selection is good and my favorite is their  "cha jong mein"  which is a pork based noodle that has a kick of spiciness to it.  My brother really enjoys their clay pots as well, if you are in the restaruant.  Best value for food, utopia Cafe is one of the best in my book.
author: Peter W.

description:
I hardly make it to Chinatown since traffic is a pain... but when I do go, I have to stop at Utopia for 2 reasons: 1) clay pots and 2) salt & pepper chicken wings. I was never a fan of clay pots until I ate here... but now I'm addicted to them, especially the chicken & mushroom clay pot rice... Such a simple meal but yet so rich in flavor... I could just eat the rice w/ the sauce over it and be a happy camper.  As for their salt & pepper chicken wings... YUM!! Crispy, juicy and soooo delish. I always need a whole order just for myself, oink, oink! 

A couple of things to note... the waitresses english is limited... so be patient! Oh ya, they validate parking.
author: Monica C.

description: Would not even give 1  star but beware ate here today the restaurant has afternoon special everyday 230 to 500. We ordered 2 things off that menu 4.00 each an appetizer 5.95, a claypot 7.95, appetizer to go 4.95 and a drink 175. The bill came to almost 36.00 the bill was not itemized and written in Chinese. As we calculated back to the car I said I will call. The young girl said because we did not say the word afternoon special even though we ordered in Chinese off this menu page in Chinese so she charged us full price. This is not right. She even argued with me that the one dish was not on the special then she looked and said oh yeah it is. Now if we can read this off the menu she will not admit they were wrong just want to rip people off. Beware got ripped off being Chinese don't go if you are a tourist. STAY AWAY FROM THIS RESTAURANT!
author: Poi L.

description:
OMG... go there and order the fried rice with pine nuts and seaweed. It sounds a little weird, but is SO GOOD! The fried rice isn't greasy at all, and the pine nuts and seaweed add interesting flavor.

Imagine, fried rice that's not oily! Amazing.
author: Kim K.

description: Wasn't overly impressed. Good value for price.
author: Gabriel P.

description:
This was my first clay pot experience, and it was really good.  We had 3 different clay pots (chicken, chinese sausage and duck, and minced pork).  I think my favorite was the chicken.  Simple flavors with just chicken and mushrooms.  I imagine this is pretty healthy too.

Sweet and sour pork was good, haven't had this in a LONG time.  
String beans were not the greatest.  This is a pretty classic dish and this one was sub-par.  
Fried Oysters were pretty good.  I was surprised, since I usually only like oysters raw.  But they weren't too greasy, and had great flavor (good sauce).

Generally pretty good food.  I'd go back for sure.
author: Kelly K.

description:
Update for 1/10/07: just had the Ginger/scallion Braised Noodles; it is listed under Noodle in Soup.  It comes with a small bowl of consomme and you use it to whet your whistle.
Since today was very cold, my body was cold too, so I thought something warm with ginger might do the trick.   The taste is wonderful ,even refreshing.The interesting flavor of ginger and scallions is sublime and untainted by any meat.  Those smart chinese!  Indeed, I'm feeling much better, not tired at all and satiated. No meat in this this dish and it's very yummy.
I like this place, it is a little harder to find but the food is tastey and the place is quiet- at least during a recent friday lunch hour.  I ordered the shredded duck with preserved cabbage and rice noodle=  it was a very yummy. I'm going back again. the list of Chef's Special's look yummy too and the various clay pot's look scrumptious as well. It is priced right too. Looking at the menu, the braised ginger and scallion noodles sound deelish. For a light lunch, $8  is ok with me. Update: yesterday, had the claypot of tofu, gluten, dried bean curd w/ black mushrooms, over a bed of lettuce. Can you eat lunch without meat ? try this wonderful vegetarian meal. Even the Tummy tiger can get paid here!
author: Bert K.

description: Tried this place out from Yelp reviews, and was so happy I did. Very unassuming from the outside, almost didn't go in, but glad we did. My 10 year old daughter who is very picky, ate almost all her adult portion of sweet and sour chicken. Very authentic, and everything we had was excellent. My daughter thought the "fish tank" in the back was cute, not realizing it's where our lunch had come from! Would definitely go back, and my cousin, who lives in SF, said he finally found a Chinese restaurant in Chinatown that he could take visitors to!
author: Lara M.

description:
I've been here a number of times because they serve Cantonese-style  clay pot rice.  The food is usually good, but the service is spotty at best.  I've had half my order forgotten here, with no apology.  

I can recommend the clay pot rice.  It's good with chicken and black mushrooms, or with ribs in black bean sauce.  All the noodle dishes I've had have been very good as well.

The downside is the service.  It's generally slow and careless, and sometimes downright rude.  As mentioned, on one visit I ordered a noodle dish and the claypot rice w/ chicken.  The noodles came, and were enjoyable.  45 minutes later, without ever having had our claypot rice they slapped the check down on the table.  When I pointed out that we'd never had half our meal, the apologized.  30 minutes later I told them to cancel the rest of the meal, and we left.  I swore I'd never go back, but I have once.  The best I can say for the service this last time is they didn't forget anything.
author: Bruce S.

description:
As I am not Chinese, nor of its ascent- I am not a qualified judge to determine whether this is "good" Chinese, or not. However, the place was full of Chinese, who when we asked, were more than happy to recommend their personal favorite dishes (thanks Kate!). Possibly we were typical tourists, but we are well travelled and fancy ourselves epicurians. Surprisingly all the regulars had differing favorite dishes which has to be a good sign, right? That said, we decided to try quite a few dishes. Everything was amazing! 
We just got off the plane from NYC today and was in its respective Chinatown over the past week, and nothing there can compare to this- and we were happy with much of what we ate in NYC and are familiar with the better spots, being former NY'ers.
That said, we delved into our plates excitedly. Ken the owner, even allowed us to try a special order he made for his daily regulars- simply Shrimp.. It was better than most lobster I have had, no exaggeration! I would consider this a destination spot on your list
author: Cindy P.

description: Great food at good price in the heart of Chinatown. The people that run it are so sweet. It is the best Chinese food I have ever had. I would recommend any of the Clay Pot dishes.
author: Clayton A.

description: I've been working in Chinatown since last December.  And I've gone on this quest for good food and tried different restaurants a couple of times a week for the past 3 months.  And this is by far the best I've had in Chinatown.  Love the food there.  I called a simple fried rice dish today.  It's unbelievably delicious.  Will definitely come back.  A real hidden gem in Chinatown.
author: Lori C.

description:
During our visit to San Francisco, we were recommended to visit here.

It's a pretty darn good place to eat, actually. Authentic Chinese food and good clay pots. Yum. Plus, since it's San Francisco, the fish is fresh too. The tea wasn't all that great, though. We visited at dinner, by the way, so it might have been the time, but I don't know.
It's good to order some of the Chinese dishes for the three-dish special. Those dishes are good as well. It's also a veggie paradise as well: Veggie Crispy Noodles, a vegetarian claypot, vegetarian fried rice, and an entire vegetarian dinner. Seriously! Needless to say, I liked this place. If I lived in SF, then I think I would come here quite a bit.
author: Edward W.

description: Brought my family here for lunch a few weeks ago.  They were able to sit us (large group) quite quickly.  I have not eaten Chinese food for several years because it is so hard to find decent Chinese food. However, because they were from out of town, we headed to China town.  I was very pleased with our food, service and the the price.  We ordered a variety of items and all of them were delicious.  The noodle dishes were spot on and the hot and sour soup was wonderful.  This is a great spot for good Chinese food.
author: Sallye M.

description:
The food here is great - especially the clay pot dishes. Having said that, if you are NOT into wasting $3...don't order any bubble tea. What a rip-off, they should take it off the menu.

Weak tea, and 7-8 bubbles total. Kid you not; makes for a horrid, disappointing drink at the beginning or end of anyone's meal. Don't waste your money.
author: Sunny D.

description: I'm not the best person to review Chinese food but on a really hungry day, very few things can be more appealing than sweet & sour soup followed by spring rolls followed by a plate full of fried rice and kung pao chicken. The kung pao chicken was well made, decorated with lots of peanuts and tasted good. This is the first Chinese restaurant that I tried in Chinatown and so I'm inclined to think there are even better Chinese places to eat out here. BTW, one small request to the folks who work here...please don't come often to take off our plates while we're still working on them :)
author: Govind R.

description: Service was ok, I think we kinda annoyed the server because the kids were playing with the lazy susan in the middle of the table. But hey they're kids. Didn't know there was a dif between pan fried noodles and Enoodles...never even heard of Enoodles. But anyways....we loved the clay pot rice with chicken and mushroom, kung pao chicken, and the enoodles. The thing that we were a little disappointed in was the salt and pepper chicken wings...it came out like peking chicken wings then the crispy MSG covered ones we're used to in SD. (Mandarin or Golden Chopsticks kind for the SD peeps who know whats up). But other than that...an experience in itself.
author: Ann T.

description: Amazing! Best Hong Kong style Chinese this side of Hong Kong!
author: Dan T.

description: Great food and the staff is very nice and helpful. I recommend the soups and the rice clap pot.
author: Viola S.

description: Great rice clay pots, everything here is pretty good. My favorite would have to be the clay pot rice, but you would have to be patience in waiting for em. If you are starving, go with the stir fry stuff, but if you are feeling for some clay pot rice, plan on spending 40 mins waiting before there is one in front of you. Also, their congee is really good!
author: Monika T.

description: I visited this restaurant with all my co-workers and there guests on Sunday, Sept 5th. We were seated in the 'Party Room" downstairs with a plasma Tv, Karaoke, and 49er colored walls. VERY VERY VERY good!!!! All of it! They were so accomodating to all of us (25 total) and made sure our water, wine, and beer glasses did not go empty! Asian culture, when they are serving you, give them so much pleasure and want you to be happy. Well,,we ALL were and I highly recommend this nice place of great food and very generous service. Parking was an issue, BUT,,we left our car at the Mason st. garage, and walked 5 blocks to the restaurant and enjoyed Chinatown scenery very much!
author: Frank V.

description: I admit that I haven't tried the special of the house - bow jai fan or clay pot rice to the gringos.   However, I cannot recommend the other items on the menu.
author: Monica L.

description: As we arrived, the "hostess" pointed toward a table in the corner and disdainfully barked an order for us to go sit there. Our teenage waitress seemed like she had been in the USA for about an hour, and the language barrier was almost impermeable. i ordered a diet Coke, and the can itself and a straw were plunked down in front of me, The meal itself was no better than anything we could get in our local suburban strip mall back home; not what we'd expect from a place in the heart of SF's Chinatown. The wontons in the soup had the consistency of a human ear wrapped in dough. The decor looked like it hadn't been redone in about 40 years, with ragged dirty upholstery on the chairs, and paint chipping off the wall. Sorry we trusted Yelp.
author: Nick D.

description:
asked for directions to the tin how temple on waverly & they "did not know where it was" (IT WAS A FEW DOORS DOWN!!!!!)

was gonna eat here, but decided against it due to the customer service.

unhelpful staff
author: Pang M.

description: This review is based on their clay pots.  That's the only dish I'd get here.  The clay pots here are the best in the city!  The perfectly crispy rice, toppings (chicken, pork, frog, and maybe one or two other selections), and the sauce is so tasty.  To die for!  I am craving it now!  I wish I was in Chinatown more often.   I would eat here all the time!  This restaurant is in an alley way.  Street parking is difficult.  I suggest parking in the Portsmouth Square garage.
author: Stacey L.

description: This is one of the best claypot rice places in SF. Mushroom and Chicken is excellent. So is the pork one. The only thing I wish was that they would give a little more chicken and pork in their claypot. But for the taste, it's up there. You'll love it.
author: Miguel T.

description: Utopia is straight urban confinement but don't let the floral wallpaper border throw you off.  The food is really REALLY good!  The cuttlefish and pork rice clay pot is five star, the Chinese broccoli was the freshest and most un-bitter I've ever had, and the wontons in the wonton soup were heaven.  Plus, cheap prices!!!  Who doesn't love good food for a bargain?
author: Lovely In L.

description: Tried their veggie fried rice, pretty good, but I thought it was kind of a small serving (but it had a variety of veggies that I don't normally see in fried rice ie water chestnuts, broccoli, etc), but my dad LOVES their wonton noodle soup and he knows wonton noodles back from his old HK days.
author: Irene L.

description: Recommended by Hotel. Location was fun. Off the beaten track on Waverly Place. Would have never gone to the Fortune Cookie factory, if we hadn't been on our way to the Utopia. Seated in the basement. Not the best, not the worst. Actually shared table with Taiweness businessman. Very nice. Service was unfriendly. Foot was OK. The beef chow mein was our favorite, chicken and mushroom clay pot...not so much. Decent, not great. Not a lot of chicken, but even that had small bits of bone in it. The carmelized rice against the clay pot was tasty.  The potstickers were very good, and the lemon chicken was OK. Again, there were a lot of little bone pieces in the chicken.
author: John F.

description: All Chinese clientele when I visited - just 4 walls and 12 or so tables at this unimposing spot on Waverly Pl.  Long-time friends who frequent chinese restaurants had been recommending for years. Clay pot dishes are the specialty.  The shrimp, scallops, fresh veggies pot was delicious, just enough minced seafood sauce to coat the ingredients. We had shrimp with glazed walnuts and pot stickers for apps.  The shrimp were lightly battered, deep-fried then coated with a custard like sauce - a different take on the standard, and outstanding.  The green beans sauteed with garlic were notable.  What stands out for me, is the sparing use of oil and sauce in Utopia's preparations.  Absolutely delicious food with no frills, little ambiance, will go back many times I hope.
author: Boom B.

description: good food guided by a guy looking for tips and he gave us a good one!
author: Ryan C.

description: We ordered salt and pepper calamari, which was excellent, and wonton soup (noodles were tasty) and the rock cod and tender greens--very nice flavor--as well as vegetable fried rice.. Appetizers were huge and one entree was more than enough for two.  Yes, the service staff is not overly friendly, but hey, this is a Chinese restaurant, not Italian or French, and they are very busy not only taking orders but getting each dish out to a table just as fast as it is ready.  Make up your mind fast, order fast, and prepare for dishes to keep coming and coming, as fresh as can be.  Notably the food is not oily, as others have observed.  And the manager was very pleasant and concerned that we were happy with our meals.  One of the best Chinese restaurants we have eaten at, with very flavorful dishes.  An added plus was that the wine was economical and quite acceptable.
author: Timothy D.

description:
utopia cafe is by far....one of the better chinese restaurants in chinatown.  

tucked away on waverly place, next to the shady double-dragon massage parlor (wonder what the outside cameras are for?), utopia serves up bomb chinese-sausage clay pots, general's tso's chicken, & salt/pepper jalapeno fried chicken wings.  sooooo yummy!

i loves me some burnt rice stuck all around the clay pot!!! 

lap cheong lap-may bo-jai fan! YES!
jiu-jeem ja gai-yik! YES!
author: Kevin W.

description: Not much for ambiance. There are florescent lights to illuminate your favorite clay pot. The servers appear stressed and are very short on conversation. The food was cheap, delicious and not as greasy as other Chinese restaurants.
author: b p.

description:
The salt & pepper chicken wings are outstanding. And that's no lie.

Every time I go back (and I go back often) I try and find something on the menu to order WITH the wings. So far nothing has been any better than average. Closest I've found is the beef chow fun, which was tasty if less than an inspired choice.

The clay pots seem popular. I'll try them next.

Service is decent. For some reason I really like the atmosphere; maybe it's the slightly-hidden location.
author: Ben P.

description: I was surprised that this place is actually pretty good- just like Chinese food should be. It's small and nested on a side street in Chinatown. The price is also good- just like Chinatown should be. Went here for work lunch and liked it! We ordered salted fish and chicken fried rice... YUMMM!!! hadn't have that in a while since I moved to SF and I am a fan of Utopia for the dish now. I also ordered some veggie dishes and crispy noodles.. really good! I will definitely come back to this place to try their  porridge and noodle soup! Needless to say... it's not fusion... and the place is full of Chinese during lunch time!
author: Daisy S.

description: I ate here after seeing a recommendation in San Francisco magazine. Alas, it was the usual Chinatown mediocre, indifferent service and items that did not bear much relation to their descriptions on the homework-plastic-cover menus. My first and last visit.
author: Harmeet D.

description:
My first visit there a few months ago was okay.   They gave us some soup while waiting for our order of clay pot and another dish.  Just one turn-off was they included service charge on the bill (we don't look like tourlists!)

We wanted to have their clay pot again, but at our second visit a few nights ago, things were little different.  All seats on the ground floor were taken so they sent us to downstairs.  The room looked like a karaoke room trying to be a banquet room; a TV screen on the wall, a storage closet with mirrored sliding doors and half-way-done drawing of cultural architecture on the wall.  

The waitress was a little rude by asking we, two of us, wanted ONLY 2 dishes.  There was not soup this time.  It took a while for the food to arrive (compare to the next table which was seated right after we were seated), but they were tasty.  

Then one of the workers came down, pointed something in the back of the room and yelled at us something we didn't understand.  Looking at that direction, I realized the floor was wet.  The water seemed to be coming from back of the room.  So we switched to another table.  A few minutes later the water was coming close to our way.  We asked if we could move to upstairs to another worker who came down, but she did not understand us.  So we just grabbed everything (purses, plates, tea cups and chopsticks) and head to upstairs.   

Those who were working upstairs were surprised that we showed up with all our dishes but also looked more concerned not to make things obvious to other customers.  They apologized and said our bill was being fixed.  That probably meant removing the service charge.  It otherwise looked nothing unusual to me.

I will probably go there again but not to downstairs!
author: April H.

description: The beef chow fun I had to-go was ginormous! I actually insisted that my friend eat some of it. This is one of those typical Chinese places, sorta like D&A  or ABC? It's pretty clean and I can get my iced honey lemon drink. I'm happy.
author: C. Z.

description: I remember going here with a few of my friends who are old geezers who hang out in chinatown too much and we ordered a few dishes. I usually order the ground chicken with salted fish in clay pot or the salted fish and chicken fried rice. good stuff! =]
author: Jason C. J.

description:
ok, this is for the AUTHENTIC chinese foodie, not the egg roll and beef and broccoli chinese fare. 

Totally yummy, simple, no frills place in Chinatown -- so don't expect splendor and immculate surroundings. 

The wontons are some of the best in the city, tasty fresh shrimp. 

The claypots were excellent, especially the rice. We got the raw cracked egg/ground beef one, and very few places can do the rice like Utopia so it's crispy and perfectly crunchy on the bottom and sides. IT is like the best treat, you wait til you get to the bottom and it's like eating rice crisps. 

We also had the lamb claypot which was very nicely done, the lamb was pretty tender. 

So... if you want serious tasty chinese homestyle food, there is a reason this place is crawling with Chinatown locals.
author: Subie C.
