description: Good food at reasonable prices. Like home cooking! Meeting a friend there for dinner tonight! Looking forward to the Claypot dinner and S&P Chicken Wings!
author: Patricia C.

description: i come here pretty often for lunch since i work nearby... the clay pot rice is worth the 20-25min wait, i usually call and order mines in advance then come in about 20mins later and I'm seated and eattin' in like 3mins lolz... the service is hit and miss here but hey it's Chinatown so I'm use to that... if your in Chinatown and want some good clay pot rice check it out, also there lunch specials are good for the $$
author: jonathan h.

description: On the night of the Chinese New Year's parade we stopped at another restaurant and could not get served. As we walked past Utiopia something caught our eye; it looked cleaner than most restaurants in the area so we went in. The service was friendly and fast. We ordered a plate rice item and one clay pot. They were both served hot and they were delicious. On the way out the owner asked us if we enjoyed our meal and welcomed us back. Our two items (including tea) with a generous tip cost $20. All in all a very good restaurant on a very special street in San Francisco. How can you beat that?
author: Top Cat S.

description:
This place is in a small alley in chinatown on Waverly Street.  We came here 2:30PM that is when the specials come out.

We had dumpling soup for $2.50....Yes.  It was good very good for that price.  The bad thing was it only had 2 dumplings

but can't complain overall for that price.
author: kenny l.

description: I expected a better experience after seeing this place on Food Tech, figured Bobbie would know where to get the goods. Service was great, but the food was rather bland and not exciting. I wont go back,,,,
author: T M.

description: solid place to go for cheap, authentic style chinese food.
author: Wayne C.

description: As my bff would tell you, I have a freakin lup cheong obsesson.  lup cheong for breakfast, lup cheong manapua, lup cheong claypot, you name it.  only thing i have to worry about is my cholestorol and spelling. my dear friend michael and i went to this restaurant after i pau work and met up with michael at his work.  we went directly to utopia restaurant and both ordered the lup cheong/preserved meat clay pot.  it was so ONO!!  the rice was perfectly crispy, the lup cheong had three flavors, liver, duck and regular and the sauce was a perfect blend of sweet and sour.  both michael and i loved our claypots.  only downside is that i speak english/pidgin and don't speak cantonese or mandorin or any other chinese dialect, so i was glad michael was there to translate.  even if he wasn't, it would have been okay.  so, if you want mind numbing, greasy, oily and delicious preserved meat on rice, i highly recommend this joint!
author: Francis G.

description: The dumpling noodle soup was good but not great.  Dumplings very tasty with some kind of peanut flavor but the noodles were a bit hard and the broth nothing special.
author: Geoffrey U.

description: Yesterday, my friends and I were around that area and were really hungry. We didn't know how to pick a restaurant, so we just picked one with a lot of old people in it. They know their stuff, right? Haha. We walked in and was greeted by the woman behind the desk. She spoke to us in English (probably because we were teenagers and had a mexican guy with us), and when I answered her in Canto, she was surprised. Anyways, we were seated in a couple of minutes. Each of us ordered our own dishes (porridge with preserved eggs & pork, salted fish clay pot, and another clay pot with squid or something). The clay pots took a while to come out, but probably because they actually cook it in the pot thing? I had the porridge and it was greeeat! Usually the egg pieces would be small, but these chunks were pretty big! I love those eggs :). The bill came out to only $20 for three dishes. Deal or waaaaht!? Gave them a big tip at the end :)
author: Olivia D.

description: well this certainly wasn't utopia (har har). i ducked in here for a quick lunch while being dragged around chinatown by my mother. they were very accommodating and courteous while she complained about being seated "in the kitchen" and demanded to have bok choy with whatever else she ordered. i got shrimp wonton soup, which was sketchy. it did have ramen in it, which was ok. mom's dish was bland. i definitely wouldn't return and probably won't since i don't plan on being dragged around chinatown again.
author: Mary V.

description: I got takeout from Utopia, so I can't say for the service, but the food was delicious.  This place is nestled in a little alley in Chinatown, and is worth checking out next time you're in the area.
author: Sharon C.
